summary.value:
Title: A Meta-analysis of the Watching Eyes Effect
Authors: Conghui Liu, Chuansheng Chen

Research Questions
Is the overall watching eyes effect robust?
Do the effects of watching eyes on outcomes (positive and negative) vary by study characteristics?
Potential Moderators:
Are the effects of watching eyes on outcome variables moderated by:
1.	Whether the data were published or unpublished? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: Studies that were published in peer-reviewed journals. 
b)	No: Studies that were not published in peer-reviewed journals (e.g., unpublished master’s theses or doctoral dissertations, unpublished conference papers, and unpublished manuscripts).
2.	What was the proportion of women in the sample?(1-100/N/A)
a)	0-100: Calculated the proportion of women using each study’s reported gender information. 
b)	N/A: Studies did not report gender information.
3.	What was the mean age of the sample?(mean age/N/A)
a)	Mean age: Calculated the average age in the entire sample.
b)	N/A: Studies did not report age information.
4.	Whether the participants were Caucasian or Asian? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: Most of the participants were Caucasian (≥50%).
b)	No: Most of the participants were Asian (≥50%).
5.	Whether the stimulus was stylized eyes versus realistic-looking eyes? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The stimulus presented to participants was a stylized image of eyes or a face.
b)	No: The stimulus presented to participants was an image of real or realistic-looking eyes or a face. 
6.	Whether the number of eyes was a single pair or multiple pairs? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The stimulus included one pair of eyes.
b)	No: The stimulus included several pairs of eyes.
7.	Whether the stimulus was presented briefly or for the duration of the experiment? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The stimulus was presented right before participants’ behaviors were measured.
b)	No: The stimulus was visible and unchanging throughout the experiment.
8.	Whether the outcomes were positive or negative? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: Positive outcomes included helping others, washing hands, voting participation, selecting healthy food, moral behavior, and social desirable responding. 
b)	No: Negative outcomes included littering, dishonesty, antisocial punishment, bicycle theft, and social undesirable responding.   
9.	Whether the responses were measured as a continuous variable or a dichotomized variable? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The outcome variable was continuous (e.g., the amount of money donated, the amount of healthy food consumed, etc.).
b)	No: The outcome variable was dichotomized (i.e., whether the participants did or did not display the behavior). 
10.	Whether the response of participants was real observed behavior or self-reported judgment? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The response of participants was real behavior (such as real monetary donations).
b)	No: The response of participants was making a judgment (merely making an attitude judgment).
11.	Whether the study was a lab versus field (online) experiment?(Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The study was performed in a laboratory.
b)	No: The study was performed in a real-world context (including the online context).
12.	Whether the experiment was a between- versus within-subjects design? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The between-subject design was used.
b)	No: The within-subject design was used.
13.	Whether the study was preregistered or non- preregistered? (Yes/No)
a)	Yes: The study was preregistered.
b)	No: The study was not preregistered.

Hypotheses
In the introduction of our manuscript, we provided our hypotheses basing on earlier studies. 

Explanations of existing data
We have collected the references of six meta-analyses (Bradley et al., 2018; Dear et al., 2019; Nettle et al., 2013; Northover, et al., 201a; Northover et al., 2017b; Sparks & Barclay, 2013; ). 
Data collection procedures
To identify relevant articles in the published or unpublished literature:
1.	Searching terms: "cues of being watched" OR "cues of observation" OR "eye cue" OR "eye cues" OR "eye images" OR "eye like" OR "eye primes" OR "eye spot" OR "eye spots" OR "eyespot" OR "eyespot effects" OR "eyespots" OR "face cues" OR "gaze cues " OR "images of eyes" OR "implicit gaze" OR "implicit observability" OR "observation cues" OR "perception of human face" OR "social cues" OR "surveillance cues" OR "watching eyes" OR "watching you" . Most of these search terms were identified by Dear (2019).
2.	The database: PsycInfo, Pubmed, Web of Science, ProQuest Dissertation, ResearchGate, psyarxiv.com, psychfiledrawer.org, and other relevant databases.
3.	Emailed the first or corresponding authors of relevant papers for unpublished data.

Sample size
We have collected 92 effect sizes from 43 studies. This number may increase as we continue to search for relevant studies and receive responses from authors of relevant articles. After collecting articles, we extracted all effect sizes from all studies that met our inclusion criteria. 

Measured variables
The effect size of interest was calculated following procedures provided by Lipsey and Wilson (2001). One meta-analysis we conducted investigated the effect of watching eyes on the amount of behavioral response (continuous variables), and the other meta-analysis investigated the effect of watching eyes on the proportion of participants who displayed a given behavioral response (dichotomized variables). 

Statistical Models
Some studies in our meta-analysis included multiple effect sizes. These effect sizes are not independent. Traditional meta-regression model did not handle the unknown correlations among dependent effect sizes. To control statistical dependency, we will use robust variance meta-regression proposed by Fisher and Tipton (2015). In our meta-regression with RVE, we will use the “correlated effects” weighting scheme and the default assumed within-study effect-size correlation (r=.08). In the sensitivity analysis, we will test the impact of assumed correlation, and report different pattern of effect size at different level of rho. The differences between traditional meta-regression and meta-regression with RVE will be explored. 

Meta-Regression Models
1. Test the overall effect using an intercept-only model.
2. Test each moderator.

Investigate publication bias
1. Examine the funnel plot with all studies included.
2. Examine the funnel plots with some studies based on moderators.
3. To detect publication bias, we will report p-curve analysis for all studies and for moderators. 
We will use the “metaphor” (Viechtbauer, 2010) and “robumeta” (Fisher & Tipton, 2015) packages in R to perform our meta-analysis. 



References
Bradley, A., Lawrence, C., & Ferguson, E. (2018). Does observability affect prosociality?. Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 285(1875), 20180116.
Dear, K., Dutton, K., Fox, E. (2019). Do 'watching eyes' influence antisocial behaviour? A systematic review & meta-analysis. Evolution and Human Behavior, 40, 269280.
Fisher, Z., & Tipton, E. (2015). Robumeta: An R-package for robust variance estimation in meta-analysis. Retrieved from http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.02220.
Lipsey, M. W., &Wilson, D. B. (2001). Practical meta-analysis. Thousand Oaks, California: Sage Publications
Nettle, D., Harper, Z., Kidson, A., Stone, R., Penton-Voak, I. S., & Bateson, M. (2013). The watching eyes effect in the Dictator Game: It's not how much you give, it's being seen to give something. Evolution and Human Behavior, 34(1), 35-40. 
Northover, S. B., Pedersen, W. C., Cohen, A. B., & Andrews, P. W. (2017a). Artificial surveillance cues do not increase generosity: Two meta-analyses. Evolution and Human Behavior, 38(1), 144-153. 
Northover, S. B., Pedersen, W. C., Cohen, A. B., & Andrews, P. W. (2017b). Effect of artificial surveillance cues on reported moral judgment: Experimental failures to replicate and two meta-analyses. Evolution and Human Behavior, 38(5), 561-571. 
Sparks, A., & Barclay, P. (2013). Eye images increase generosity, but not for long: The limited effect of a false cue. Evolution and Human Behavior, 34(5), 317-322. 
Viechtbauer, Wolfgang. (2010). Conducting meta-analyses in R with the metafor package. Journal of Statistical Software, 36(3), 1-48.

summary.value:
シャーデンフロイデがどのような条件下で喚起されるかは、この感情の研究において大きな関心事であった。その中でも、他者の経験する苦難に対する相応性はシャーデンフロイデ喚起の重要な要因とされている。ただし、どのような苦難を相応であると評価するかは、個人がどのような応報に関する信念を持つかによって異なると予測される。したがって、シャーデンフロイデが喚起される条件も、それによって変わると考えられる。そこで本研究では、報いとしての応報・仕返しとしての応報という応報信念の区別（Gerber & Jackson, 2013）を援用し、これら信念と苦難に対する相応性評価およびシャーデンフロイデの関連を検討する。具体的には、まず参加者の応報に関する信念の測定を行い、次に規範違反者が苦難（懲罰・私的な罰・プライベートでの災難など）を経験するというシナリオを呈示する。そして、これに対する相応性・シャーデンフロイデを測定する。報いとしての応報信念が強い人は、規範違反による被害・損害の程度と違反者が経験する苦難の程度がバランスの取れた場合に、最相応しいと評価すると考えられるため、この場合にシャーデンフロイデも最も強く経験するだろう。一方、仕返しとしての応報信念が強い人は、規範違反と苦難のバランスよりも、違反者がより苦しむ場合に相応しいと評価すると考えれる。したがってこうした人は、規範違反による被害・損害に対して与えられる苦難が過剰である場合に、シャーデンフロイデを強く経験するだろう。

詳細はadditional informationとして添付した（pdf）

attributes.title: Examining the Impact of Item Attributes on the Faking Resistance of Personality Inventories

q1.value: Examining the Impact of Item Attributes on The Faking Resistance of Personality Inventories

q2.value: Andrew Perossa, Chet Robie, Wahyu Widhiarso

q3.value: Personality inventories (PIs) help organizations select the best suited employees, but the prevalence of applicant faking calls into question whether PIs identify the best applicants or the best liars (Robie et al., 2007). This proposed study would test a proactive, item-level method of PI faking prevention: construct-irrelevant item attributes (CIIAs). CIIAs are contextual attributes of items, such as time frame (i.e., whether an item asks about past or future behaviour). These attributes are grouped into opposite pairs of attribute values (e.g., past vs. future, definite vs. indefinite). Widhiarso et al. (2019) found that if PI items are designed using some of these attributes, participants are less likely to fake their responses to them; making the items faking resistant. Widhiarso et al. (2019) also found that each attribute pair contained an attribute that made items more relatively resistant to faking than its opposite attribute. The present study is a conceptual replication and extension of this work. I propose that participants will be less likely to fake their responses to items written to incorporate these resistant attributes. To test this hypothesis, I will conduct an experiment in which participants are instructed to either answer these items honestly or fake their responses as if applying for a job. I will determine the faking resistance of each attribute by testing whether items designed with that attribute show uniform differential item functioning. These findings would support the efficacy of an underutilized yet widely applicable faking prevention method, improving the validity of PIs as selection tools.

q4.value:
H1: Items that incorporate resistant attributes will be resistant to faking such that these items will not show significant uniform differential item functioning

H2: Items that incorporate resistant attributes will be more relatively resistant to faking than their opposite attributes such that these items will show relatively less uniform differential item functioning

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This a two-group, between-subjects, experimental, online study. In this study, participants complete two personality inventories, both measuring conscientiousness. The first is the Original Conscientiousness Inventory (OCI). This scale is based on the NEO Five-Factor Inventory (NEO-FFI) developed by Costa and McCrae (1989). The second is the Modified Conscientiousness Inventory (MCI). This scale contains items that incorporate the seven resistant attribute values as well as their opposites. 
This study contains two experimental conditions: honest and faking. Participants in both conditions will complete the OCI. Participants will be instructed to complete the OCI as honestly as possible. Then, participants in the honest group will complete the MCI under the same honest instructions. Participants in the faking condition will instead read a job description for a financial analyst and be instructed to complete the MCI as if they were applying for that job and wanted to make the best impression possible.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through an advertisement posted to the research participation system of a Canadian university’s business school. Participants who are enrolled in a business class at this school have the option to participate in research through this system to fulfill a course requirement. Participants will receive this course credit for their participation. Sessions will be held at an on-campus computer lab. Sessions will last 30 minutes and involve an estimated 20 participants per session. We have approval to recruit 600 participants through this system during the Winter 2020 semester, which ends April 28, 2020. If we are unable to collect data from at least approximately 500 participants, we may continue data collection in the Spring 2020 semester, which takes place between May 4, 2020 and August 13, 2020.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 550, with approximately 225 in each of the honest and faking conditions. We will recruit 600 assuming that not all will complete the tasks.

q14.value: I aim to use a sample of similar size to that used by the study I am replicating. Widhiarso et al. (2019) executed their study with 543 participants.

question.value: We are measuring latent conscientiousness through scores on the OCI, honest scores on the MCI, and faked scores on the MCI.

We will first use confirmatory factor analysis to fit a unidimensional model to each group with Mplus. Comparative fit index, root mean square error of approximation, and Tucker-Lewis index will be used to determine goodness of model fit. These models treat each response to an item (1,2,3,4, and 5) as its own categorical variable. It estimates the thresholds for each of these variables using the weighted least square mean and variance estimator. In this case, the thresholds are the level of latent conscientiousness that a participant would require to have a greater than 50% probability of selecting that response or higher. These five thresholds are then averaged to get item location parameters. Then, we will use multi-group CFA. In Mplus, it is Model 5.16 Multiple group CFA with covariates (Multiple Indicator Multiple Cause Model) with categorical factor indicators and a threshold structure. OCI scores are the covariate. The comparative fit index, root mean square error of approximation, and Tucker-Lewis index will be used to determine model fit. It uses the weighted least square mean and variance estimator.
Then, to determine whether uniform differential item functioning (DIF) is present, the MGCFA will be repeated 14 times, each with a different omnibus Wald test, one for each attribute value.

q21.value:
Faking resistance is defined by whether an item shows uniform DIF. So, if items from a category do not show uniform DIF, as evidenced by a non-significant Wald test, that attribute value will be determined to be resistant to faking, supporting Hypothesis 1. The significance of Wald statistics is assessed at the .05 alpha level. 
A Comparative fit index of greater than 0.90, a Tucker-Lewis index of greater than .95, and a root mean square error of approximation of greater than .06 will be taken to indicate good model fit. However, since this study is a replication, I will still conduct the analyses if these fit indices are below their cutoffs. In fact, Widhiarso et al.’s (2019) analysis was conducted despite only achieving “acceptable” model fit, rather than good fit, due to low root mean square errors of approximation. 
To determine whether an attribute is more resistant to faking than its opposite value, the key criterion is number of items that are affected by DIF. If fewer of one attribute’s items are affected by DIF than its opposite attribute’s items are, then it will be considered more relatively resistant to faking.

q22.value: We will put a standard attention check in the second scale. Participants who fail the attention check will be excluded from the analysis. There will also be a manipulation check at the end of the MCI: “I completed the previous personality test as seriously as I would if I were applying for an actual job.” This item is on a 5-point Likert Scale. Responses below 3 will be excluded.

q23.value:
In order to run a MGCFA, MPlus requires that participants across groups have chosen the same number of response options. The analysis would fail if for instance, several participants in the faking condition selected “strongly agree” on an item, but no one in the honest condition did so. So, if some responses have not been chosen, individuals' responses to the missed categories will be collapsed into their nearest categories. This decision is not based on any concrete rule but is a common practice that was used by the study we are replicating (Widhiarso et al., 2019).
If a participant fails to answer an item, the missing response will be considered to be missing completely at random and handled using the weighted least squares estimation.

q25.value:
References

Costa, P. T., & McCrae, R. R. (1989). The NEO-PI/NEO-FFI manual supplement.
Psychological Assessment Resources.

Robie, C., Brown, D. J., & Beaty, J. C. (2007). Do people fake on personality inventories? A 	verbal protocol analysis. Journal of Business and Psychology, 21(4), 489–509. 	https://doi.org/10.1007/s10869-007-9038-9 

Widhiarso, W., Steyer, R., & Ravand, H. (2019). Exploring a proactive measure of making items 	of a personality questionnaire resistant to faking: An employee selection setting. 	Personality and Individual Differences, 149, 1–7.							https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2019.05.040

This proposed study would test a proactive, item-level method of PI faking prevention: construct-irrelevant item attributes (CIIAs). CIIAs are contextual attributes of items, such as time frame (i.e., whether an item asks about past or future behaviour). These attributes are grouped into opposite pairs of attribute values (e.g., past vs. future, definite vs. indefinite). Widhiarso et al. (2019) found that if PI items are designed using some of these attributes, participants are less likely to fake their responses to them; making the items faking resistant. Widhiarso et al. (2019) also found that each attribute pair contained an attribute that made items more relatively resistant to faking than its opposite attribute. The present study is a conceptual replication and extension of this work. I propose that participants will be less likely to fake their responses to items written to incorporate these resistant attributes. To test this hypothesis, I will conduct an experiment in which participants are instructed to either answer these items honestly or fake their responses as if applying for a job. I will determine the faking resistance of each attribute by testing whether items designed with that attribute show uniform differential item functioning. These findings would support the efficacy of an underutilized yet widely applicable faking prevention method, improving the validity of PIs as selection tools.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: Items that incorporate resistant attributes will be resistant to faking such that these items will not show significant uniform differential item functioning

H2: Items that incorporate resistant attributes will be more relatively resistant to faking than their opposite attributes such that these items will show relatively less uniform differential item functioning
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 550, with approximately 225 in each of the honest and faking conditions. We will recruit 600 assuming that not all will complete the tasks.
registration_responses.q14: I aim to use a sample of similar size to that used by the study I am replicating. Widhiarso et al. (2019) executed their study with 543 participants.
registration_responses.q21:
Faking resistance is defined by whether an item shows uniform DIF. So, if items from a category do not show uniform DIF, as evidenced by a non-significant Wald test, that attribute value will be determined to be resistant to faking, supporting Hypothesis 1. The significance of Wald statistics is assessed at the .05 alpha level. 
A Comparative fit index of greater than 0.90, a Tucker-Lewis index of greater than .95, and a root mean square error of approximation of greater than .06 will be taken to indicate good model fit. However, since this study is a replication, I will still conduct the analyses if these fit indices are below their cutoffs. In fact, Widhiarso et al.’s (2019) analysis was conducted despite only achieving “acceptable” model fit, rather than good fit, due to low root mean square errors of approximation. 
To determine whether an attribute is more resistant to faking than its opposite value, the key criterion is number of items that are affected by DIF. If fewer of one attribute’s items are affected by DIF than its opposite attribute’s items are, then it will be considered more relatively resistant to faking.
registration_responses.q22: We will put a standard attention check in the second scale. Participants who fail the attention check will be excluded from the analysis. There will also be a manipulation check at the end of the MCI: “I completed the previous personality test as seriously as I would if I were applying for an actual job.” This item is on a 5-point Likert Scale. Responses below 3 will be excluded.
registration_responses.q23:
In order to run a MGCFA, MPlus requires that participants across groups have chosen the same number of response options. The analysis would fail if for instance, several participants in the faking condition selected “strongly agree” on an item, but no one in the honest condition did so. So, if some responses have not been chosen, individuals' responses to the missed categories will be collapsed into their nearest categories. This decision is not based on any concrete rule but is a common practice that was used by the study we are replicating (Widhiarso et al., 2019).
If a participant fails to answer an item, the missing response will be considered to be missing completely at random and handled using the weighted least squares estimation.
registration_responses.q25:
References

Costa, P. T., & McCrae, R. R. (1989). The NEO-PI/NEO-FFI manual supplement.
Psychological Assessment Resources.

Robie, C., Brown, D. J., & Beaty, J. C. (2007). Do people fake on personality inventories? A 	verbal protocol analysis. Journal of Business and Psychology, 21(4), 489–509. 	https://doi.org/10.1007/s10869-007-9038-9 

Widhiarso, W., Steyer, R., & Ravand, H. (2019). Exploring a proactive measure of making items 	of a personality questionnaire resistant to faking: An employee selection setting. 	Personality and Individual Differences, 149, 1–7.							https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2019.05.040
registration_responses.q8.question:
This a two-group, between-subjects, experimental, online study. In this study, participants complete two personality inventories, both measuring conscientiousness. The first is the Original Conscientiousness Inventory (OCI). This scale is based on the NEO Five-Factor Inventory (NEO-FFI) developed by Costa and McCrae (1989). The second is the Modified Conscientiousness Inventory (MCI). This scale contains items that incorporate the seven resistant attribute values as well as their opposites. 
This study contains two experimental conditions: honest and faking. Participants in both conditions will complete the OCI. Participants will be instructed to complete the OCI as honestly as possible. Then, participants in the honest group will complete the MCI under the same honest instructions. Participants in the faking condition will instead read a job description for a financial analyst and be instructed to complete the MCI as if they were applying for that job and wanted to make the best impression possible.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited through an advertisement posted to the research participation system of a Canadian university’s business school. Participants who are enrolled in a business class at this school have the option to participate in research through this system to fulfill a course requirement. Participants will receive this course credit for their participation. Sessions will be held at an on-campus computer lab. Sessions will last 30 minutes and involve an estimated 20 participants per session. We have approval to recruit 600 participants through this system during the Winter 2020 semester, which ends April 28, 2020. If we are unable to collect data from at least approximately 500 participants, we may continue data collection in the Spring 2020 semester, which takes place between May 4, 2020 and August 13, 2020.
registration_responses.q17.question: We are measuring latent conscientiousness through scores on the OCI, honest scores on the MCI, and faked scores on the MCI.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will first use confirmatory factor analysis to fit a unidimensional model to each group with Mplus. Comparative fit index, root mean square error of approximation, and Tucker-Lewis index will be used to determine goodness of model fit. These models treat each response to an item (1,2,3,4, and 5) as its own categorical variable. It estimates the thresholds for each of these variables using the weighted least square mean and variance estimator. In this case, the thresholds are the level of latent conscientiousness that a participant would require to have a greater than 50% probability of selecting that response or higher. These five thresholds are then averaged to get item location parameters. Then, we will use multi-group CFA. In Mplus, it is Model 5.16 Multiple group CFA with covariates (Multiple Indicator Multiple Cause Model) with categorical factor indicators and a threshold structure. OCI scores are the covariate. The comparative fit index, root mean square error of approximation, and Tucker-Lewis index will be used to determine model fit. It uses the weighted least square mean and variance estimator.
Then, to determine whether uniform differential item functioning (DIF) is present, the MGCFA will be repeated 14 times, each with a different omnibus Wald test, one for each attribute value.

attributes.title: Probing the Mental Representation of Relation-defined Categories

q1.value: Probing the Mental Representation of Relation-defined Categories

q3.value: Though prototype and exemplar theories have widely explained the mental representation of feature-based concepts, the mental representation of relation-based concepts is unclear. We will train participants with concepts that can be categorized by either relation-based strategy or feature-based strategy, examine which strategy is used by a transfer task, and measure how these concepts will be represented via a reconstruction task.

q4.value:
Given the outcome of the transfer task, participants who have already passed the training phase can be divided into separate groups – relation-based strategy users and feature-based strategy users. For our primary outcome of the training task, we hypothesize that 1a) there will be an interaction between how the concepts are learned (relation-based strategy or feature-based strategy) and how the environments are built (probabilistic or deterministic), such that 1b) the performance (measured by pass rate, the number of trials used to pass) will be worst in probabilistic relation-based condition, as the probabilistic relation-based concepts are hard, if not impossible, to be learned.
For our primary outcome of the reconstruction task, we hypothesize that 2) if people have learned the deterministic concept using the relation-based strategy (i.e. pass the training phase in deterministic condition, and are detected as relation-based strategy users), they will be more willing to use extremely unseen values to reconstruct a good example of the learned concept.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a 2 (relation-based vs. feature-based strategy) x 2 (probabilistic vs. deterministic environment) between-subjects design. While only the environment variable is manipulated, the strategy variable is measure through a transfer task. Within each deterministic condition, there are four sub-conditions where one out of four dimensions (number of cells, number of hairs, size of area and aspect ratio) serves as the deterministic dimension.

q9.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions, and further randomly assigned to one of four sub-conditions if they are in the deterministic condition. 
In the training phase, a two-choice categorization task is used to instruct the concepts. Depending on whether the task is built in probabilistic or deterministic environments, each block will include 8 or 12 trials, and the order of trials within each block will be randomized. In the transfer phase, we present a highly similar two-choice categorization task, and each block will include 16 or 12 trials. Also, the order of trials within each block will be randomized. For trials that can only be solved by relation-based strategy, the value used to depict the stimuli will be randomly selected from a uniform distribution. Finally, among all trials, the locations of the two choices will be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the REP web portal of the Ohio State University. Depending on which condition they are assigned to, they will 35 (deterministic conditions) or 50 (probabilistic conditions) minutes to finish the task and be given 0.5 or 1 REP credit. Participants must be at least 18 years old to participate.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 80 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 120, assuming that not all will pass the attention checks.

q14.value: Given that probing mental representation of relation-defined concepts is a novel attempt, it is hard to have a rational estimate of the effect size. Therefore, the sample size mentioned above is based on our experience in similar studies.

question.value:
We manipulated how stimuli were conducted in a 2 x 2 design (relation-based vs. feature-based strategy x probabilistic vs. deterministic environment). The environment variable is manipulated.
On each trial, participants will see two kinds of elliptical cells (i.e. red and blue), which differ in four dimensions (in addition to their colors): number of cells, number of hairs of each cell, size of area of each cell, and aspect ratio of each cell. In each condition, we manipulate how the values of these four dimensions are chosen. Participants will be informed that the cells reflect one of two fictional diseases – “Azolitis” and “Leporidis”, and their job is to make the diagnosis. Concretely, in Azolitis prototype the red cells are more numerous (6 vs. 4/3 cells), have more hairs (6 vs. 4/3 hairs), larger (1200 vs. 800~600 pixels), and less elongated (60% vs. 40~30%). 
In probabilistic condition, exemplars will be constructed by taking three relations from the prototype of the corresponding category and the fourth relation from the prototype of the opposite category, so that each dimension is 75% diagnostic of category membership during the task. In deterministic conditions, on the other hand, exemplars will also be constructed by taking three relations from the corresponding category and the fourth relation from the opposite category, one dimension (depends on which sub-condition it is) will always be taken from the corresponding category so that this particular dimension is 100% diagnostic.

The outcome variables from training, transfer and reconstruction phases will be collected. 
During the training phase, the responses of categorization and the corresponding response time will be collected. When participants make at most one mistake in each block of three consecutive blocks, they will enter the transfer phase. Therefore, whether passing the training phase and the number of trials used to pass the training phase is used as measured variables. 
During the transfer phase, two kinds of stimuli will be presented. One kind of stimuli can only be solved by relation-based strategy, as only the relations hold (i.e in Azolitis prototype red cells are more numerous, have more hairs, larger, and less elongated) but both red and blue cells are depicted by values randomly selected from a uniform distribution (3~7 in the number of cells, 3~7 in the number of hairs, 600~1400 square pixels in size of area, and 30%~70% in aspect ratio). The rest of stimuli, on the other hand, can only be solved by feature-based strategy, as only the specific features hold (i.e in Azolitis prototype both red and blue cells have 6 cells, 6 hairs, and approximately have area of 1200 square pixels and an aspect ratio of 60%) but the relations are no longer differentiable. Therefore, we record the accuracy of these two kinds of stimuli to detect which strategy is used by each participant.
During the reconstruction phase, a total of ten questions like "Reconstruct a good example of category Azolitis/Leporidis" will be asked, and participants are required to answer by adjusting four pairs of values in eight sliders to adjust the ellipses. The ranges of values provided to choose from are 2~ 8 in the number of cells, 2~ 8 in the number of hairs, 400~1600 square pixels in size of area, and 20%~80% in aspect ratio. The selected values used to reconstruct good examples are measured variables in the reconstruction phase. During reconstruction, participants will be instructed to press the "ignore" button next to each slider to show that they intend to ignore this particular dimension, therefore, the condition of pressing "ignore" buttons are also the measured variables.

The sequence of responses will be divided by a sliding window of length 3 into shorter sequences (e.g. "AAA', "AAL", "ALA", LAL" for "AAALAL"). The frequencies of these eight (2*2*2) sequences will be used as a measure of attention.

A two (relation-based vs. feature-based strategy) by two (probabilistic vs. deterministic environment) mixed ANOVA will be conducted for our first hypothesis, in which the dependent variables will be the trials used to pass the criterion in training phase (assigned to 312 trials if the failed to pass the criterion). The measured strategy variable will depend on the responses during the transfer task, and a variant of the Expectation-Maximization algorithm will be used to classify relation-based strategy users from feature-based strategy users.
As for the results from the reconstruction task, a two (relation-based vs. feature-based strategy) by three (probabilistic dimensions vs. deterministic dimensions vs. non-deterministic dimensions in deterministic conditions) mixed ANOVA will be used, in which the dependent variables will be the degree of extremeness and relation magnitude. Concretely, degree of extremeness refers to the degree that participants adjust the sliders. Take the number of cells dimension as an example, all stimuli in the reconstruction task have 5 red cells and 5 blue cells, by adjusting the sliders the number of cells can be changed to as few as 2 cells and as many as 8 cells. If a participant leaves a good example with 2 red cells and 8 blue cells, the degree of extremeness will be 3 for both cases (i.e. take the absolute of the difference). The other dimensions will be standardized to the scale of 0~3 for degree of extremeness as well. On the other hand, the relation magnitude refer to the magnitude of the relation between red and blue cells upon each dimension. If a participant gives an example of Azolitis with 2 red cells and 8 blue cells, the corresponding relation magnitude should be -6, as the prototype of Azolitis has more red cells than blue cells. 
In addition, we further classified participants as reliant or non-reliant on the basis of their training data. Concretely, we calculate the correlation between the binary classification responses during the last 48 trials of the training sequence and the binary relational values of each dimension. If the correlation of one dimension is larger than 0.783 (i.e. statistically significant greater correlation than 0.67), we assume that the participant relies on this particular dimension. Based on this, another two (relation-based vs. feature-based strategy) by three (rely on this dimension vs. rely on other dimensions vs. never rely on any dimensions) mixed ANOVA will be conducted. The dependent variable will be the degree of extremeness and relation magnitude as well.

q20.value:
As indicated above, the range of values used to depict stimuli in the transfer task (3~7 in the number of cells, 3~7 in the number of hairs, 600~1400 square pixels in the size of area, and 30%~70% in the aspect ratio) is narrower than the range of values provided to choose from in reconstruction task (2~8 in the number of cells, 2~8 in the number of hairs, 400~1600 square pixels in the size of area, and 20%~80% in the aspect ratio). We recoded the midpoints of all dimensions as 0.0, and the other corresponding values from -3.0 to + 3.0, so that the effects of dimensions can be compared directly. 
The other transformations are mentioned in the statistical model module.

q21.value: The standard p<.05 criteria will be used to determine if the ANOVA tests confirm our hypotheses.

q22.value:
The pipeline is used to exclude the participants who skip over the experiment to get paid without trying to do the task.  
1.	Participants who pass the criterion will be kept. See step 2 to 4 for those participants who fail to pass the criterion.
2.	If the median of response time is smaller than 0.5 sec, the data will be discarded.
3.	As indicated above, the sequence of responses will be divided by a sliding window of length 3 into 8 types of short sequences. If the proportion of any type of sequence is larger than 0.3, the data will be discarded.
4.	As for the attention checks, if one fail in more than one attention check, the data will be discarded.
5.	For participants who fail to pass the criterion but remain through step 2 to 4, the data will be kept.

q23.value: Participants may close the window halfway in the experiments. In such a case, the data will be discarded.

attributes.title: Disclosure and Well-being Across Cultural Groups

q1.value: Disclosure and Well-being Across Cultural Groups

q4.value:
H1: We expect that the association between self-disclosure and outcomes will be moderated by culture. By culture, we refer to cultural group and cultural values. We expect that European Americans will show the strongest association between self-disclosure and well-being outcomes, and that Asian Americans will show the weakest association between self-disclosure and well-being outcomes. We do not have any specific predictions about the 
association between self-disclosure and well-being outcomes for Latinx participants and are keeping this part of our analyses exploratory.

H2: We expect that the association between capitalization and outcomes will be moderated by culture. By culture, we refer to cultural group and cultural values. We expect that European Americans will show the strongest association between capitalization and well-being outcomes, and that Asian Americans will show the weakest association between capitalization and well-being outcomes. We do not have any specific predictions about the association between capitalization and well-being outcomes for Latinx participants and are keeping this part of our analyses exploratory.

H3: Group differences on cultural values 
There will be significant group differences between the three cultural groups and their cultural values.

European Americans will be high on emotional expressivity and ideal high arousal positive affect.

Asian Americans will be high on harmony values, loss of face, modest behavior, and ideal low arousal positive affect. Asian Americans will be low on emotional expressivity.

Latinx participants will be high on simpatía, emotional expressivity, attitudinal familism, and ideal high arousal positive affect. 

We will also examine self-disclosure and capitalization to family and friends and their associations with well-being outcomes across culture (cultural group and cultural values) on an exploratory basis.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional, correlational survey study.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data has been accessed for data cleaning purposes. In addition, only demographic distributions have been observed, but no analyses in relation to hypotheses have been conducted.

question.value:
Population: In order to be eligible for participation, our participants must be at least 18 years old and identify with one of the following cultural groups: European Americans (3rd generation and beyond), Latinx/Latinx Americans (1st or 2nd generation), and Asian Americans (1st or 2nd generation). 

Compensation: In the case of students taking an introductory psychology class at Haverford College, participants will be awarded 0.5 research credit. Other participants will be compensated through a $5 e-gift card of their choice to either Amazon or Starbucks.

Recruitment: Participants will be recruited through Haverford College’s introductory psychology courses, Haverford College’s class Facebook groups, as well as affinity groups across the Tri-College Consortium (Haverford, Bryn Mawr, and Swarthmore Colleges).

q13.value:
We intend to have between 40 and 50 participants in each cultural group. Therefore, we hope to collect data from 40-50 European Americans, 40-50 Latinx/Latinx Americans, and 40-50 Asian/Asian Americans, constituting a total sample size of between 120 to 150 participants.

The final sample size was 66 total participants with 28 Asian Americans, 17 Latinx participants, and 22 European Americans.

question.value:
After obtaining informed consent, participants will complete a demographics questionnaire. They will then complete questionnaires assessing their willingness to disclose to friends and family, as well as single-item capitalization questions that ask participants to report on whether they share and celebrate their positive events with friends and family [Self-disclosure Index (Miller, Berg, Archer, 1983);
Capitalization question (used in Choi, Oishi, Shin, & Suh, 2019)]. 

 Participants will also complete various measures that assess cultural differences such as differences in: emotional expressivity, affect valuation (idealizing of certain affective states over others), modest behavior, harmony values, familism (measuring familism, a cultural orientation to prioritizing family needs over one’s own), simpatía (valuation of positive, congenial interactions), and loss of face (valuation of public social esteem) [Emotion Expressivity Questionnaire (EEQ) (King & Emmons, 1990); Affect Valuation Index (AVI) (Tsai, Knutson, & Fung, 2006); Modest Responding Scale (MRS) (Whetstone, Okun, Cialdini, 1992); Harmony Values Scale (Lau & Shih, 2006); Attitudinal Familism Scale (Steidel & Contreras, 2003), Big Five Inventory (Agreeableness sub-scale to measure simpatía) (BFI) (John & Srivastava, 1999); Loss of Face Scale (LOF) (Zane, 2000)].

Participants will then complete a series of measures assessing various aspects of well-being and related outcomes, such as a measure of mood, social anxiety, perceived social support, and overall relationship quality [Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS) (Watson, Clark, Tellegen, 1988); Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (SIAS) (Mattick & Clark, 1998); Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (MSPSS) (Zimet, Dahlem, Zimet & Farley, 1988)].
We will be using moderated multiple regression to test for main hypotheses. We will use ANOVA to test for group differences.

q24.value: Referencing prior research that has looked at cultural differences in social support from family and friends, we expect that there would be differences in the association between self-disclosure and capitalization to different targets (family and friends) and their associations with well-being across culture (cultural group and cultural values). Therefore, we intend to conduct exploratory analyses to examine family and friend disclosure and capitalization and their associations with well-being across culture (cultural group and cultural values).

registration_responses.q1: Disclosure and Well-being Across Cultural Groups
registration_responses.q4:
H1: We expect that the association between self-disclosure and outcomes will be moderated by culture. By culture, we refer to cultural group and cultural values. We expect that European Americans will show the strongest association between self-disclosure and well-being outcomes, and that Asian Americans will show the weakest association between self-disclosure and well-being outcomes. We do not have any specific predictions about the 
association between self-disclosure and well-being outcomes for Latinx participants and are keeping this part of our analyses exploratory.

H2: We expect that the association between capitalization and outcomes will be moderated by culture. By culture, we refer to cultural group and cultural values. We expect that European Americans will show the strongest association between capitalization and well-being outcomes, and that Asian Americans will show the weakest association between capitalization and well-being outcomes. We do not have any specific predictions about the association between capitalization and well-being outcomes for Latinx participants and are keeping this part of our analyses exploratory.

H3: Group differences on cultural values 
There will be significant group differences between the three cultural groups and their cultural values.

European Americans will be high on emotional expressivity and ideal high arousal positive affect.

Asian Americans will be high on harmony values, loss of face, modest behavior, and ideal low arousal positive affect. Asian Americans will be low on emotional expressivity.

Latinx participants will be high on simpatía, emotional expressivity, attitudinal familism, and ideal high arousal positive affect. 

We will also examine self-disclosure and capitalization to family and friends and their associations with well-being outcomes across culture (cultural group and cultural values) on an exploratory basis.

attributes.title: Survey 5 - Censorship of Flat Earth Videos Qualtrics Sample

q1.value: Alternative Beliefs: Survey 5 - Censorship of YouTube Videos - Qualtrics Sample

q3.value: This is the third data collection related to the third person effects of flat earth videos study. In the first two surveys, participants' religiosity was a very strong predictor of third person perceptions: people who were low in religiosity. One reason for this may be that our samples came from MTurk. Moreover, the desire to censor the videos was generally low. This may be due to the fact that our samples were restricted to regular YouTube users. This survey will seek to determine whether our findings hold with a more nationally representative sample with diverse YouTube use.

q4.value:
H1. Participants will rate each of the identity groups as finding the video more convincing then they, themselves, do, except when rating people who attended graduate school.

H2. Participants’ own political party affiliation and religiosity would be the two strongest predictors of third person perceptions (TPP scores). TPP scores will be calculated by subtracting participants' own ratings of "convincingness" from their perceptions of other's convincingness ( 'Other' Group minus Self).

H3. Social distance will predict third-person scores above and beyond the other individual characteristics. 

H4. Greater third-person perceptions will predict greater call for censorship scores.

H5. Third Person perceptions will account for a greater proportion of the variance in calls for censorship scores than the individual differences variables, such as political ideology and YouTube use.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is a within-subjects design. First, participants are asked questions about their use of YouTube. Second, participants will be shown a 5-minute YouTube video. Participants are given the option to hit "next" after one minute. Then, participants are asked questions about the video, including how convincing they find it. Third, participants are asked about how convincing others will find the video. Fourth, participants are asked whether the videos, video creators, and YouTube ought to be censored in a variety of ways. Fifth, participants are asked about their own views (conspiracy mentality questionnaire and science views). Sixth, participants are asked to rate how simliar or different they are to the various identity groups asked about earlier. Finally, participants are asked standard demographic questions. Note that some of the demographic questions may be moved to the beginning to be used for quota sampling by Qualtrics.

q9.value: For some of the questions, the response levels are randomized. And for some of the question blocks, the question orders are randomized. See the survey draft attached to the previous question.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited by Qualtrics and compensated in line with Qualtrics rules and regulations. Participants will be sampled using quota sampling to match U.S. census breakdowns along gender, race/ethnicity, age, and education as closely as possible. Participants must be 18 or older to participate and live in the United States. Data will be collected in early January 2020.

q13.value: We requested a sample of 1000 participants from Qualtrics.

q14.value: Sample size is based off of our prior studies and our financial limitations.

q15.value: Data collection will cease once Qualtrics has collected the 1000 participants.

question.value: N/A

The variables of primary importance to our analysis are below. For the rest of the measured variables, please see our survey.

Convincingness. After watching the video, participants were reminded of the argument made and were asked how convincing they found it to be using a slider scale that ranged from 0 (not convincing) to 100 (extremely convincing). Later in the survey, participants were asked to rate how convincing they think other types of people might find the video. These “other” groups were described as follows: Republicans, Democrats, people who think the Bible should be interpreted literally, people who do not believe God exists (atheists), people who live in rural areas (country), people who live in urban areas (cities), people who did not go to college, and people who have graduate degrees.

TPP scores.  Difference in perceived susceptibility (i.e., the third person perception, or TPP scores) will be obtained by subtracting the participants’ own rating of the argument’s convincingness from their expectations of how convincing each of the “other” groups of people would find the argument (e.g., TPP = Other Group – Self Rating). Therefore, TPP scores could range from +100 (indicating that the participant thinks the “other” would be completely convinced whereas the participant is not at all convinced) to -100 (indicating that the participant is completely convinced and thinks that the other would not be convinced at all) for each of the eight different “other” groups (e.g., TPP_Rural = Rating for people who live in rural areas – rating for the self; TPP_Biblit = Rating for people who believe the Bible should be interpreted literally – rating for the self). Participants were asked about each of the following identity groups: Republicans, Democrats, biblical literalists, atheists, rural dwellers, urban dwellers, people who didn’t go to college, and people who attended graduate school.

Conspiracy mentality will be measured using the 5-item generalized conspiracy mentality scale by Bruder and colleagues (2013). Participants will be shown each statement, such as “many important things happen in the world, which the public is never informed about”, and asked whether the statement is (1) definitely false, (2) probably false, (3) probably true, or (4) definitely true. The scale will be analyzed using item response theory and cronbach’s alpha and combined into an averaged index.

Call for Censorship. We will ask participants about censoring flat Earth videos on YouTube. For these items, participants will be shown a series of statements and asked to what extent they agreed or disagreed with those statements (strongly disagree = 1 to strongly agree = 6). The statements include asking participants whether YouTube should:
•	shut down or delete channels that upload flat Earth videos; 
•	ban users who upload flat Earth videos; 
•	delete videos that argue the Earth is;
•	demonetize channels that upload flat Earth videos; 
•	refrain from recommending flat Earth videos to other users; and 
•	be fined for distributing flat Earth videos. 
As for our second study preregistration, we stated we will create an averaged index using these items so long as the items have good inter-item reliability (Cronbach’s alpha > .80) and a scree “acceleration factor” test shows evidence for one factor. It is worth noting in our second study, however, that the non-graphical solutions (e.g., parallel analysis, optimal coordinates analysis) suggest a two-factor solution. We may see this for this survey as well. If this is the case, we will report an analysis using the two-factor solution in an appendix. 

Social Distance. We will also ask participants to rate how similar or dissimilar people from various groups are to themselves (e.g., Eveland, Nathanson, Detenber, & McLeod, 1999). Participants will read the following: “For each of the following identity groups, please tell us whether you feel that the people in this group—whether you belong to the group or not—are a lot like you or not at all like you. Like for the self-report and the third person ratings, participants answered this question using a slider scale from 0 (Not at all like me) to 100 (A lot like me). Participants were asked about each of the identity groups they rate earlier in the survey, including Republicans, Democrats, biblical literalists, atheists, rural dwellers, urban dwellers, people who didn’t go to college, and people who attended graduate school.

Religiosity. Participants will be asked two questions to gauge their religiosity: (1) how much guidance does your faith, religion, or spirituality provide in your day-to-day life on a 6-point scale (not religious to a great deal) and (2) do you pray, and if so, how often, on a 5-point scale (I don’t pray to at least daily). These two items will be centered and scaled before being averaged together and rescaled. 

Political party affiliation. To gauge political party affiliation, we ask participants the following: “When there is an important election, what do you do most of the time?” Participants are given 5 response options: vote for the Democrat, vote for the Republican, vote for an independent or third-party candidate, ‘I don’t vote’, or ‘other (please specify)’. Then, Don’t vote, other, and no response will be combined into one category labeled “other” (consistent with study 2). This variable will be treated as categorical with Democrat as the referent in all analyses.

YouTube use. Unlike our previous studies that restricted the sample to regular YouTube users, we opened our sample up to a more nationally representative sample and measured YouTube use with the following question: “How often do you watch videos on YouTube” with the following response options: Seldom/Never, Just a few times a year, Monthly, Weekly, or Daily.
See attached file for analysis plan and code

There are 2 attention checks. 

First, we will ask participants if the person who harmed them was punished (yes or no). We will exclude participants who do not follow instructions. So, participants assigned to the condition where they are instructed to recall an event in which the other person was punished will be excluded if they report that the other person was not punished. Similarly, participants assigned to the condition where they are instructed to recall an event in which the other person was not punished will be excluded if they report that the other person was punished.

Second, the study will end with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants will select one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses. 

Participants who fail at least one of these 2 attention checks will be excluded from our analyses.

dependent.value: We will asked participants the extent to which their social worlds seem structured, orderly, predictable, understandable, chaotic, and random on a 7-pt scale (1 = not at all, 7 = very much so). The latter two items (chaotic and random) will be reverse-scored. We will then take an average across the 6 items to get a composite. If the items do not show adequate reliability (Chronbach's alpha below .65), we will treat each of the 6 items as separate DVs (i.e., no composite).

conditions.value:
There are two conditions to which participants will be assigned in a between-subjects fashion:
1. Participants recall an event in which someone else intentionally harmed them and was punished.
2. Participants recall an event in which someone else intentionally harmed them and was NOT punished.

hypothesis.value: Is it the case that making salient memories in which someone broke a moral rule (i.e., people should not intentionally harm other people) and was punished (vs. not punished) makes the social world seem more predictable and orderly?

attributes.title: INvestigating Child Learning: Understanding Dual-language Environments (INCLUDE)

q1.value: INvestigating Child Learning: Understanding Dual-language Environments (INCLUDE)

q3.value:
Bilingualism has practical benefits in an increasingly globalized world, as well as cognitive benefits essential for academic achievement. Children who are Dual Language Learners (DLLs) in the Head Start program may develop English and their home language in distinctly different patterns. Think, for example, of a DLL student who excels at communicating in both English and Spanish compared to a child with strong Spanish and emerging English skills. While Head Start program policy clearly requires classrooms to support DLL students, a “one-size-fits-all” approach to support DLL students will not meet the needs of this diverse group.
Research indicates there are meaningful differences in school readiness indicators between groups of children who have different patterns of Spanish-English dual language development. Findings indicate that children who have the most even proficiency between languages reap the most benefits. While this reiterates the importance of maintaining home languages while supporting English growth, it is unclear how early care environments influence the joint development of English and Spanish.
Individually testing environmental impacts on each language separately may inadvertently miss critical information about the “whole” DLL student. The approach proposed in this project is innovative as it considers the impacts of early care environments on both English and Spanish development simultaneous rather than inspecting each language individually.  Understanding the complex interplay between home and classroom influences and the simultaneous development of two languages will provide opportunities for programs and families to work together to individualize services for this unique population.

q4.value:
RQ 1. Does latent dual language group membership differentially predict behavior outcomes?
H 1. Children in latent groups with English or Spanish vocabulary in the average range will have better behavioral outcomes as compared to those who have delays in either language (Halle et al., 2014). As language skills increase, behavior problems decrease indicating we can expect the same from this group (Brownlie et al., 2004; van Daal, Verhoeven & van Balkon, 2007). It is excepted that proficiency in either Spanish or English would be related to positive behavioral outcomes because Head Start Performance Standards directly address DLLs’ unique cultural and linguistic needs (U.S. Dept. of HHS, 2016) thus providing an underlying structure to support children who are proficient in Spanish regardless of their English language proficiency.
RQ 2. After controlling for demographic factors, are there significant differences between latent dual language groups in terms of family and home environment factors?
H 2. Based on research indicating that parent use of their native language predicts children’s grammatical abilities in that language (Gutiérrez-Clellen & Kreiter, 2003), and the home learning environment positively impacts child language development (Payne, Whitehurst, & Angell, 1994; Raikes et al., 2006; Sénéchal & LeFevre, 2001; Tabors, Roach, & Snow, 2001; Tamis-LeMonda, Bornstein, & Baumwell, 2001), we hypothesize that home environmental context (e.g. number of people, books, and materials in the home in Spanish) and values/practices (e.g. frequency of activities to support language, parent language proficiency, parent value of home language), will impact latent dual language group membership.
RQ 3. For each latent dual language group, how do factors within the classroom impact behavior outcomes?
H 3.  Based on documented behavioral impacts for children who are unable to communicate well with teachers and peers (Olsen, 1997) and the positive relation between classroom quality and child behavior (Halle et al. 2010)  it is expected that there will be differences between latent language groups in terms of the impact of classroom and teacher characteristics on child behavior.

question.value:
To identify the latent dual language groups, a parallel process latent growth model (LGM) will be conducted to simultaneously estimate the growth curves for English and Spanish.  LGM is the covariance structural equation model (SEM) representation of the multilevel model (MLM) for change. LGM is capable of adjusted standard errors for data that is nested. This is important given the structure of the current study (i.e., time nested within individuals). LGM fits a growth model with fixed (i.e., average level) and random (i.e., variability around the average) effects and correctly estimates adjusted standard errors.  In short, this is a flexible and powerful methodological approach capable of estimating growth curve models to test hypotheses about within-person change over time (i.e., intraindividual change) and between-person differences in change over time (i.e., interindividual change; Bollen, 2014; Ram & Grimm, 2007; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002; Singer & Willett, 2003).  In addition, results using these methods are robust to missing data. Due to attrition over time in the FACES dataset, not all cases are complete. The most typical method for handling incomplete (or missing) data is by using maximum likelihood estimation. This estimation method assumes repeated measures are continuous and normally distributed. Preliminary analyses will be inspected to ensure the selected data meet these assumptions.
LGM in Mplus was chosen because of some distinct advantages that fit the
 current proposal’s analytical needs: (a) the ability to handle item missing data on both the outcomes and the predictors via utilization of full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation; (b) the ability to assess model fit via global fit statistics (e.g., Confirmatory Fit Index [CFI]) to analytically evaluate and determine the best-fitting growth model; (c) the ability to model and analyze changes in multiple variables, and relationships among multiple variables, simultaneously (Chou et al., 1998; Diallo, Morin,& Parker, 2014; Ferrer et al., 2004; Willett, 2004 ).
A limitation of the previous study was inability to test non-linear trajectories. Due to the number of missing cases at the fourth time point (kindergarten) the previous project selected to only included three timepoints whereas four time points are required to test quadradic slopes. However, with twice the sample size afforded by linking the 2006 and 2009 studies, it is expected that sufficient cases from Spanish-speaking households will be available at the final data collections point to test latent quadratic slopes (non-linear trajectories). This is an important extension of the previous research with receptive language particularly because a similar study using expressive language detected non-linear dual language patterns (Escobar & Tamis-LeMonda, 2017).
As a first step to conduct a parallel process analysis, separate models will be fitted to English and Spanish vocabulary raw scores, thus, all of the following steps will be completed for English and Spanish separately. First, intercept-only first-order latent growth curve models (LGCM) will be examined. In the baseline models, all cases will be considered to have identical growth patterns, means, variances, and covariances. All parameters are constrained to be equivalent across groups. In essence, the model is forced to assume all students belong to a single-group.
Next, fit statistics for linear and non-linear LGC models will be compared to intercept-only models. Then, random effects of the linear models were inspected. In contrast to fixed-effects (i.e., the sample's mean value for intercept and slope) random effects indicate the amount of variability around the sample's mean value for intercept and slope. In order to proceed with investigating if time-invariant predictors explain variability in random effects, these values must be statistically significant. The addition of covariates is intended to explain the observed variability around the sample’s mean intercept and slope. If random effects are statistically significant, child gender (the only time-invariant covariate planned for inclusion) will be entered on the slopes and intercepts of the two separate models. Covariates will be set to their individual variances as a requirement of time-invariant variables in LGCM. If child gender is not statistically significant it will be dropped from the final parallel process model.
The two resulting models (one for Spanish, one for English) will be combined into a single parallel-process model. Residual variances for each outcome variable will be constrained to be equal over the three measurement occasions. Syntax will be added to prompt the generation of data-driven groups based on students’ Spanish and English language scores. To account for the possibility that there may be more or fewer unobserved groups than hypothesized, models were tested with 2, 3, 4, and 5 group solutions. Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) was compared between models to determine the best-fitting model (Nylund, Asparouhov, & Muthén, 2007). The number and nature of groups in the final best fitting model will be described.
A total of 905 cases are expected to be available for analyses. Using an equation for estimating power in latent class analyses (Dziak, Lanza, & Tan, 2014) a model with 3 classes, and 4 variables (Spanish vocabulary, English vocabulary, and child gender), an effect size of .17 is needed to have 80% power to reject the null hypothesis with the current estimated sample size. This ranges between the benchmarks for a small (.10) and medium (.30) effect size (Cohen, 1988).
Research question one:   Does latent dual language group membership differentially predict behavior outcomes? A multivariate regression analysis will test the relation between latent language group and behavior outcomes. In this analysis, dual language membership will essentially be treated as a categorical variable as assigned through the process described above. As a precaution, an intraclass correlation coefficient analyses will first be conducted to inspect the proportion of between-unit variance to total variance. As described previously, FACES used a multi-stage clustered sampling technique. Unlike simple random sampling, it is expected that observations are not independent because there are inherent clusters at each stage of sampling. Children in the same program, center, or classroom, are more likely to share similar characteristics due to being drawn from the same environment. An intraclass correlation will be conducted at the program, center, and teacher level to describe how similar student’s scores are at each level. The intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs), indicate the proportion of between-unit variance to total variance. In addition to providing contextual information about language scores, the presence of significant clustering can lead to considerable bias in the results of tests of statistical significance in conventional OLS regression analyses, which does not take the dependence of observations into account (Cohen, Cohen, West & Aiken, 2003). In previous work using data from Spanish-speaking children in the FACES dataset has not indicated a significant amount of clustering that requires a more complex analytic method to account for clustering and it is expected a regression analysis will be sufficiently sophisticated to answer research questions one. 
Descriptive analyses and preliminary correlations of all variables of interest will first be inspected to ensure the distribution of scores relation between covariates and outcomes meet assumptions. Latent dual language group will be dummy coded based on model generated assignment. Regression analysis has been selected because it allows for the inclusion of multiple covariates to be entered into the model. This will be important as we expect to include family demographic variables, child gender, and initial behavioral scores as control variables in order to tease out the distinct impact of language group on behavior. With a total sample size of 905 cases a power analysis, using G*Power, indicates that an analysis with an error probability of p < .05, testing 5 predictors (e.g. child gender, initial behavior, maternal education, length of time in the U.S, and family income) has sufficient power (.92) to detect a small effect (.02).
The results will provide links from a holistic view of dual language development to behavior development. Results will inform discussions with the partner Head Start site to develop person-centered strategies focused on the unique strengths and needs of DLL students in the Head Start program. 
Research question two: After controlling for demographic factors, are there significant differences between latent dual language groups in terms of family and home environment factors? An analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) will be used to address this research question. This technique allows for the inspection of between group differences on key family and home environment outcomes while accounting/controlling for differences that might be attributable to group membership. ANCOVA is used to remove noise from the analysis that was induced by random differences between groups. Because it is impossible to randomly assign children to be a part of a specific dual language group, group assignment is not randomized meaning there may be confounding effects on the outcome variable of interest. Thus, this analytic method would permit controlling for demographic variables, such as maternal education, to inspect the specific differences between group averages on the family outcome variable of interest.
Understanding how family and home environment factors differ between groups can provide clues for programs to understand what developmental pattern a child might be headed towards beyond their presenting language ability. Findings may additionally provide insight into key variables that meaningfully impact child language development which may prove to be useful points of leverage for families as they make choices that guide children toward the language development trajectory of most value to them.
Research question three: For each latent dual language group, how do factors within the classroom impact behavior outcomes? An intercepts-and-slopes-as-outcomes multilevel regression analysis (Luke, 2004) will be used to answer this question. This type of analysis allows researchers to inspect both random intercepts and random slopes with predictors at both the individual level and the cluster level. 
Most importantly, this approach allows for the ability to test potential interaction effects between the individual level predictors and cluster level predictors. This means that we can inspect whether there is a difference between dual language groups in respect to how classroom level variables, such as teacher education, impact child behavior. Teacher education is a cluster level variable because it varies between, but not within, each Head Start classroom. In other words, all the children in the same classroom are experiencing the same teacher characteristics. The impact these cluster level variables have on behavior outcomes will provide direction for person-specific strategies for teachers. Results would provide direction to tailor classroom support to meeting the unique needs of DLL children based on differences observed based on latent dual language group.

q11.value: This project is exploratory in nature. The authors have previously worked with data from the FACES:2009 study. Addition of the FACES:2006 study will be new to the authors.

question.value:
FACES is a series of longitudinal studies of Head Start classrooms, children, and families. Researchers follow 3- and 4-year-old children from their first year in a Head Start classroom until their first year in kindergarten. Data is collected at the program, center, classroom, child, and family level. A major limitation of the previous study the current proposal is building upon was that the smallest group of children had such a limited sample size that it may have not had the power necessary to address subsequent questions. FACES, with its successive nationally representative samples, provides descriptive data from different years’ studies (FACES 2014, 2009, 2006, 2003, and so on) that may be used to analyze trends and changes in the Head Start program, the population enrolled, and the services provided. For example, it is possible to combine data from FACES 2006 and FACES 2009, as is planned for the current study. Participation rates in FACES are historically high and a total of 905 cases from Spanish-speaking households are expected to be available for analyses (456 cases from 2006; 449 cases from 2009). To facilitate cross-study comparisons, the content and naming of the measures used in the FACES instruments is structured with considerable overlap. This means that once the variables and sample of interest have been selected from each study, the files can be merged to increase the overall sample size available for planned analyses.
FACES data collection in 2006 and 2009 occurred in three waves that followed children from their first year in Head Start until the spring of their kindergarten year. Only children who are coded as Spanish-speakers, have not been identified as having a speech or language disorder at any assessment wave, and were three years old at the first wave of data collection, thus having an opportunity to experience two full years of Head Start before kindergarten, will be included in analyses. FACES data are used to answer questions about children who are dual language learners (DLL) and attend Head Start, particularly with respect to a congressionally mandated report on such children. Thus, each study provides detailed information relevant to DLL students. Additionally, for many children from non-English homes, Head Start may be the first fully immersive English experience where they are expected to participate and learn making it a critical scene to investigate dual language development and the surrounding care context.
