Receptive vocabulary in English and Spanish was measures using the Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test (PPVT) and Test de Vocabulario en Imágenes Peabody (TVIP; Dunn, Padilla, Lugo, & Dunn, 1986) respectively. The PPVT was administered to all children in the study, regardless of home language, and the TVIP was administered to all children whose parents indicated their primary home language was Spanish.  Both measures are designed to measure receptive vocabulary of participants from age 2 and a half years to adults (Dunn & Dunn, 2006). Administration and scoring is similar across measures. Participants are shown picture plates with four pictures and asked to point to the picture that best represents a stimulus word presented orally by the examiner. The items are presented in order of increasing difficulty. Testing is discontinued after participants have made eight or more errors in a set of 12 stimulus words. One point is awarded for each correct response, and the sum of the correct responses is used as the index of receptive vocabulary. Scores may be converted into standard scores, with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15 (Dunn & Dunn, 2007). The administration manual notes the following about the PPVT’s application to English language learners: 
“The PPVT-4 instrument was normed exclusively on individuals who are proficient in English, and therefore it would not be best practice to report a normative score on this test for an individual who is not English proficient. As a criterion measure, however, the PPVT-4 scale is useful for assessing the extent and nature of a person’s knowledge of standard American English words. The early item sets of each PPVT-4 form include high-frequency, commonly used words. These words can aid in screening individuals for whom English is not the primary language and in planning interventions for those who want to attain English proficiency.” (Dunn & Dunn, 2007, p.3)
Split-half reliability and alpha coefficients are consistently high at all ages and grades (Dunn & Dunn, 2007). The FACES User Guide indicates that the Cronbach alpha scores across time points ranged from 0.91 to 0.97 for the PPVT and 0.89 to 0.94 for the TVIP (Malone et al., 2013). Average test-retest reliability is reported to be .93 (Malone et al., 2013). The PPVT demonstrates convergent validity as it has been found to correlate with two established tests of expressive vocabulary: the Expressive Vocabulary Test, Second Edition (.80 to .84), and the Comprehensive Assessment of Spoken Language (mid-.60s to high .70s; Dunn & Dunn, 2007). All children participating in FACES testing were administered the PPVT. Split half reliabilities of the TVIP range from .80 to .94 (Dunn et al., 1986). The content validity of the measure with the Kauffman Assessment Battery for Children Spanish ranged from .25 to .56 and concurrent validity was .44 with the Habilidad General Ability Test (Dunn et al., 1986).
Child gender will be included as a control variable in analyses targeted at identifying latent language groups because gender has been shown to influence language development in both monolinguals and bilinguals. Studies of monolingual language development report female children tend to have a larger vocabulary than males of the same age (Huttenlocher, Haight, Bryk, Seltzer, & Lyons, 1991). Studies of DLL students have mixed results related to whether gender makes a significant impact on English language learning (Greenberg-Motamedi, 2015; Grissom, 2004; Thompson, 2017; Uriarte et al., 2011), or experience no differences related to dual language development vocabulary (Hammer, Davison, Lawrence, & Miccio, 2009).
Child Problem and Prosocial Behavior were both collected from both parents and teachers. Taken together, the parent and teacher ratings permitted a comparison of assessment items for a given child and allowed construction of composites of children’s social behavior across settings and data sources. However, given that different behaviors may be more or less salient in the home versus the classroom, a subset of items in the rating scales is unique to each setting and data source.
Parents and teachers were asked to rate each child on a set of behaviors that assessed the child’s basic social skill and behavior problems. The ratings included items drawn from the Personal Maturity Scale, Social Skills Rating System (SSRS; Gresham and Elliott 1990; Elliott et al. 1988) and Behavior Problems Index (BPI; Peterson and Zill 1986). Teachers and parents indicated the extent to which a given statement (such as “makes friends easily”) was characteristic of the child, from 1 (“never”) to 3 (“very often”). Summary scores were created from the three-point scale items.
Items in the FACES behavior problems scale, which measure negative child behaviors associated with learning problems, come from an abbreviated adaptation of the Personal Maturity Scale and from the Behavior Problems Index (BPI; Peterson and Zill 1986). The BPI included undercontrol (such as aggression, hyperactivity, and destructiveness) and overcontrol (such as social withdrawal, depression, and somatic problems) behaviors; the internal consistency of the BPI total score ranged from 0.88 to 0.89 in the National Health Interview Survey and the National Longitudinal Study of Youth (NLSY) (Berry et al. 2004). Given that the BPI does not adequately assess pro-social or positive behaviors, additional items for the parent and teacher rating scales were taken from the SSRS and from the Personal Maturity Scale..
The Personal Maturity Scale was originally used in the 1976–1977 National Survey of Children (Zill and Daly 1993) and later adapted by Alexander and Entwisle for use in their longitudinal study of achievement of Baltimore’s inner-city elementary school children (Alexander and Entwisle 1988). The scale, which measured a child’s interest or participation, cooperation or compliance, and attention span or restlessness, consists of 13 items forming three subscales, with alpha reliabilities ranging from 0.74 to 0.85. The SSRS social skills scale’s alpha coefficients range from 0.87 to 0.90 for parent reports across the elementary and preschool SSRS forms, respectively, and 0.94 for the teacher forms.
Parent interviews were collected from participating families via computer-assisted personal and telephone interviews conducted in Spanish and English. A rich resources of information is available including demographic information (e.g. immigration status, maternal education), information specific to the presence and value of Spanish in the home (e.g. number of people, books, and materials in the home in Spanish, how proficient the respondent is in English in Spanish, how valuable home and English language is to the respondent), and questions addressing the home learning environment. 
In FACES, information about activities with children come from previous national surveys, including the NHES and Home Observation for Measurement of the Environment (HOME) Inventory, a standard measure of the quality of the language and learning environment in the home. FACES obtained information about the frequency of various types of stimulating or educational activities with the child, such as singing songs or nursery rhymes, counting together, visiting the park, and shopping or running errands. These items, drawn from national surveys, were used to form scales that assessed the parent’s participation in the child’s educational experiences and cognitive stimulation. 
Classroom variables available for analyses include observational measures of quality, teacher characteristics, and curriculum and support specific to DLL students. Observational measures of the classroom include the Instructional Support (instructional support, concept development, and language modeling) domain of the Classroom Assessment Scoring System (CLASS; Pianta et al., 2008) and the Early Childhood Environment Rating Scale–Revised (ECERS–R).   
The CLASS observes and assesses the quality of interactions between teachers and students in classrooms and measures aspects of interactions related to children’s early academic achievement and social competencies. Each dimension is rated on a seven-point scale (1 = “minimally characteristic” to 7 = “highly characteristic”) for each of four observation cycles. For Instructional Support domain, publisher-reported internal consistency = 0.79, correlation between two observations as an indicator of test-retest reliability = 0.86, and average inter-rater reliability (within one point of rating from master raters) is 87 percent (Pianata et al., 2008). 
The Early Childhood Environment Rating Scale–Revised (ECERS–R) is a global rating of classroom quality based on structural features of the classroom (Harms et al. 2005). The classroom environment is defined as the use of space, materials, and experiences to enhance children’s development, daily schedule, and supervision. Even though child development research has made wide use of the ECERS–R to predict optimal child outcomes (for example, Phillips et al. 1994), research studies have not consistently supported the seven-scale factor structure of the full ECERS–R (Malone et al. 2010). Accordingly, FACES used a subset of items from the ECERS–R which has also been used by the Multi-State Study of Prekindergarten, the State-Wide Early Education Program (SWEEP; Early et al. 2005), and the Chicago Program Evaluation Project (C-PEP) study (Ross et al. 2008). The items in the short form represent the strongest 21 items identified by researchers in a large-scale study (Clifford et al. 2005) and form two factors: Teaching and Interactions (that is, the quality of teacher-child interactions) and Provisions for Learning (that is, materials available in the classroom and the arrangement of the classroom space). Each of the two factors encompasses 11 to 12 items, with each item rated on a seven-point scale that denotes a level of quality associated with the scale score. A score of one is considered “inadequate,” 3 is “minimal quality,” 5 is “good quality,” and 7 is “excellent quality.” In spring 2010 and spring 2011 of FACES 2009, the internal consistency reliability (Cronbach’s alpha) for the Teaching and Interactions mean score and the Provisions for Learning mean score ranged, respectively, from 0.84 to 0.85 and from 0.80 to 0.84. For the ECERS–R, inter-rater reliability for the full scale ranges from 0.85 (rank-order correlations) to 0.92 (Pearson), and inter-rater reliability on individual items reached agreement of 71 percent for agreement within one point. Internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha) ranged from 0.71 (parents and staff) to 0.88 (activities), with an alpha coefficient of 0.92 for the full scale (Harms et al. 2005).
Teacher characteristics, are a set of structural factors related to child care quality, include teacher education and training. The Head Start teacher interview asked about the classroom teacher’s teaching experience (number of years teaching in Head Start), educational background (the highest grade or year of school completed), teaching credentials (for example, Child Development Associate), salary, and demographics (age, gender, race/ethnicity). Additionally, teacher’s Teachers’ knowledge and beliefs about best teaching practices for early childhood education was collected using 15 statements representing opinions on how Head Start children should be taught and managed (Burts et al. 1990). Two statements posit that “Head Start classroom activities should be responsive to individual differences in development” and “Students should work silently and alone on seatwork.” The Head Start teacher indicated whether and to what extent he or she agreed or disagreed with each statement based on a five-point Likert type scale (1 = “strongly disagree”; 5 = “strongly agree”).
Presence of overt DLL support provided is also collected through questions asked in teacher and program interviews. Surveys ask about what specific curriculum are used and if there is guidance provided to support language development of DLL children. Respondents were asked questions about the language demographic in the classroom such as how many adults and children in the classroom speak Spanish, who in the classroom uses Spanish for instruction and speaking to the group, and the availability of materials in Spanish in the classroom. Finally, interviews also asked teachers to rate their proficiency speaking and understanding Spanish.

Preliminary analyses will be inspected to ensure the selected data meet these assumptions.
LGM in Mplus was chosen because of some distinct advantages that fit the
 current proposal’s analytical needs: (a) the ability to handle item missing data on both the outcomes and the predictors via utilization of full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation; (b) the ability to assess model fit via global fit statistics (e.g., Confirmatory Fit Index [CFI]) to analytically evaluate and determine the best-fitting growth model; (c) the ability to model and analyze changes in multiple variables, and relationships among multiple variables, simultaneously (Chou et al., 1998; Diallo, Morin,& Parker, 2014; Ferrer et al., 2004; Willett, 2004 ).
A limitation of the previous study was inability to test non-linear trajectories. Due to the number of missing cases at the fourth time point (kindergarten) the previous project selected to only included three timepoints whereas four time points are required to test quadradic slopes. However, with twice the sample size afforded by linking the 2006 and 2009 studies, it is expected that sufficient cases from Spanish-speaking households will be available at the final data collections point to test latent quadratic slopes (non-linear trajectories). This is an important extension of the previous research with receptive language particularly because a similar study using expressive language detected non-linear dual language patterns (Escobar & Tamis-LeMonda, 2017).
As a first step to conduct a parallel process analysis, separate models will be fitted to English and Spanish vocabulary raw scores, thus, all of the following steps will be completed for English and Spanish separately. First, intercept-only first-order latent growth curve models (LGCM) will be examined. In the baseline models, all cases will be considered to have identical growth patterns, means, variances, and covariances. All parameters are constrained to be equivalent across groups. In essence, the model is forced to assume all students belong to a single-group.
Next, fit statistics for linear and non-linear LGC models will be compared to intercept-only models. Then, random effects of the linear models were inspected. In contrast to fixed-effects (i.e., the sample's mean value for intercept and slope) random effects indicate the amount of variability around the sample's mean value for intercept and slope. In order to proceed with investigating if time-invariant predictors explain variability in random effects, these values must be statistically significant. The addition of covariates is intended to explain the observed variability around the sample’s mean intercept and slope. If random effects are statistically significant, child gender (the only time-invariant covariate planned for inclusion) will be entered on the slopes and intercepts of the two separate models. Covariates will be set to their individual variances as a requirement of time-invariant variables in LGCM. If child gender is not statistically significant it will be dropped from the final parallel process model.
The two resulting models (one for Spanish, one for English) will be combined into a single parallel-process model. Residual variances for each outcome variable will be constrained to be equal over the three measurement occasions. Syntax will be added to prompt the generation of data-driven groups based on students’ Spanish and English language scores. To account for the possibility that there may be more or fewer unobserved groups than hypothesized, models were tested with 2, 3, 4, and 5 group solutions. Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) was compared between models to determine the best-fitting model (Nylund, Asparouhov, & Muthén, 2007). The number and nature of groups in the final best fitting model will be described.
A total of 905 cases are expected to be available for analyses. Using an equation for estimating power in latent class analyses (Dziak, Lanza, & Tan, 2014) a model with 3 classes, and 4 variables (Spanish vocabulary, English vocabulary, and child gender), an effect size of .17 is needed to have 80% power to reject the null hypothesis with the current estimated sample size. This ranges between the benchmarks for a small (.10) and medium (.30) effect size (Cohen, 1988).
Research question one:   Does latent dual language group membership differentially predict behavior outcomes? A multivariate regression analysis will test the relation between latent language group and behavior outcomes. In this analysis, dual language membership will essentially be treated as a categorical variable as assigned through the process described above. As a precaution, an intraclass correlation coefficient analyses will first be conducted to inspect the proportion of between-unit variance to total variance. As described previously, FACES used a multi-stage clustered sampling technique. Unlike simple random sampling, it is expected that observations are not independent because there are inherent clusters at each stage of sampling. Children in the same program, center, or classroom, are more likely to share similar characteristics due to being drawn from the same environment. An intraclass correlation will be conducted at the program, center, and teacher level to describe how similar student’s scores are at each level. The intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs), indicate the proportion of between-unit variance to total variance. In addition to providing contextual information about language scores, the presence of significant clustering can lead to considerable bias in the results of tests of statistical significance in conventional OLS regression analyses, which does not take the dependence of observations into account (Cohen, Cohen, West & Aiken, 2003). In previous work using data from Spanish-speaking children in the FACES dataset has not indicated a significant amount of clustering that requires a more complex analytic method to account for clustering and it is expected a regression analysis will be sufficiently sophisticated to answer research questions one. 
Descriptive analyses and preliminary correlations of all variables of interest will first be inspected to ensure the distribution of scores relation between covariates and outcomes meet assumptions. Latent dual language group will be dummy coded based on model generated assignment. Regression analysis has been selected because it allows for the inclusion of multiple covariates to be entered into the model. This will be important as we expect to include family demographic variables, child gender, and initial behavioral scores as control variables in order to tease out the distinct impact of language group on behavior. With a total sample size of 905 cases a power analysis, using G*Power, indicates that an analysis with an error probability of p < .05, testing 5 predictors (e.g. child gender, initial behavior, maternal education, length of time in the U.S, and family income) has sufficient power (.92) to detect a small effect (.02).
The results will provide links from a holistic view of dual language development to behavior development. Results will inform discussions with the partner Head Start site to develop person-centered strategies focused on the unique strengths and needs of DLL students in the Head Start program. 
Research question two: After controlling for demographic factors, are there significant differences between latent dual language groups in terms of family and home environment factors? An analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) will be used to address this research question. This technique allows for the inspection of between group differences on key family and home environment outcomes while accounting/controlling for differences that might be attributable to group membership. ANCOVA is used to remove noise from the analysis that was induced by random differences between groups. Because it is impossible to randomly assign children to be a part of a specific dual language group, group assignment is not randomized meaning there may be confounding effects on the outcome variable of interest. Thus, this analytic method would permit controlling for demographic variables, such as maternal education, to inspect the specific differences between group averages on the family outcome variable of interest.
Understanding how family and home environment factors differ between groups can provide clues for programs to understand what developmental pattern a child might be headed towards beyond their presenting language ability. Findings may additionally provide insight into key variables that meaningfully impact child language development which may prove to be useful points of leverage for families as they make choices that guide children toward the language development trajectory of most value to them.
Research question three: For each latent dual language group, how do factors within the classroom impact behavior outcomes? An intercepts-and-slopes-as-outcomes multilevel regression analysis (Luke, 2004) will be used to answer this question. This type of analysis allows researchers to inspect both random intercepts and random slopes with predictors at both the individual level and the cluster level. 
Most importantly, this approach allows for the ability to test potential interaction effects between the individual level predictors and cluster level predictors. This means that we can inspect whether there is a difference between dual language groups in respect to how classroom level variables, such as teacher education, impact child behavior. Teacher education is a cluster level variable because it varies between, but not within, each Head Start classroom. In other words, all the children in the same classroom are experiencing the same teacher characteristics. The impact these cluster level variables have on behavior outcomes will provide direction for person-specific strategies for teachers. Results would provide direction to tailor classroom support to meeting the unique needs of DLL children based on differences observed based on latent dual language group.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses will involve the specific behavior outcomes related to dual language groups, and the specific classroom and home environment factors associated with outcomes.

q25.value: Previous research completed by the research team for the current proposal explored patterns of receptive Spanish and English language development, and identified subgroups of Head Start children with different language trajectories (Juhasz, Dotterer, & Boyce, 2018 ). Extant data from the Family and Child Experiences Survey (FACES:2009) were analyzed. Children from Spanish-speaking households who were three years old when they participated in the study were selected for analyses.  Data were collected at three time points spanning two full years of Head Start participation. Parallel-process latent growth models identified three patterns of dual language development. The smallest group (Average English and Spanish) was characterized by standard scores of English and Spanish in the ‘Average’ range across time. The second group (Moderately Low Increasing to Average English; Stable Average Spanish) showed Spanish and English standard scores that were closely related across time. Standard scores for this group were on the cusp between the ‘Average’ and ‘Moderately Low’ ranges. The final, and largest, group (Increasing Extremely Low English; Stable Average Spanish) had Spanish standard scores in the ‘Average’ range across time and English standard scores that increased more than one standard deviation, to ‘Moderately Low,’ by Head Start exit. Effects of group membership on executive functioning scores at Head Start exit were tested and showed that children with similar standard scores in English and Spanish across time, performed statistically significantly better on the executive functioning task than children in the largest group suggestions that the positive relation between bilingualism and executive function may be due to cascading effects between overlapping processes. However, a limitation of this study was that the smallest group of children had such a limited sample size that it may have not had the power necessary to address subsequent questions. The current proposal address this limitation by linking the 2006 and 2009 FACES studies to effectively double the sample size available. Furthermore, the current proposal takes the additional step of not only investigating how latent language groups predict school-readiness outcomes, but also the impact of early language environments on patterns of dual language development.

registration_responses.q1: INvestigating Child Learning: Understanding Dual-language Environments (INCLUDE)
registration_responses.q3:
Bilingualism has practical benefits in an increasingly globalized world, as well as cognitive benefits essential for academic achievement. Children who are Dual Language Learners (DLLs) in the Head Start program may develop English and their home language in distinctly different patterns. Think, for example, of a DLL student who excels at communicating in both English and Spanish compared to a child with strong Spanish and emerging English skills. While Head Start program policy clearly requires classrooms to support DLL students, a “one-size-fits-all” approach to support DLL students will not meet the needs of this diverse group.
Research indicates there are meaningful differences in school readiness indicators between groups of children who have different patterns of Spanish-English dual language development. Findings indicate that children who have the most even proficiency between languages reap the most benefits. While this reiterates the importance of maintaining home languages while supporting English growth, it is unclear how early care environments influence the joint development of English and Spanish.
Individually testing environmental impacts on each language separately may inadvertently miss critical information about the “whole” DLL student. The approach proposed in this project is innovative as it considers the impacts of early care environments on both English and Spanish development simultaneous rather than inspecting each language individually.  Understanding the complex interplay between home and classroom influences and the simultaneous development of two languages will provide opportunities for programs and families to work together to individualize services for this unique population.
registration_responses.q4:
RQ 1. Does latent dual language group membership differentially predict behavior outcomes?
H 1. Children in latent groups with English or Spanish vocabulary in the average range will have better behavioral outcomes as compared to those who have delays in either language (Halle et al., 2014). As language skills increase, behavior problems decrease indicating we can expect the same from this group (Brownlie et al., 2004; van Daal, Verhoeven & van Balkon, 2007). It is excepted that proficiency in either Spanish or English would be related to positive behavioral outcomes because Head Start Performance Standards directly address DLLs’ unique cultural and linguistic needs (U.S. Dept. of HHS, 2016) thus providing an underlying structure to support children who are proficient in Spanish regardless of their English language proficiency.
RQ 2. After controlling for demographic factors, are there significant differences between latent dual language groups in terms of family and home environment factors?
H 2. Based on research indicating that parent use of their native language predicts children’s grammatical abilities in that language (Gutiérrez-Clellen & Kreiter, 2003), and the home learning environment positively impacts child language development (Payne, Whitehurst, & Angell, 1994; Raikes et al., 2006; Sénéchal & LeFevre, 2001; Tabors, Roach, & Snow, 2001; Tamis-LeMonda, Bornstein, & Baumwell, 2001), we hypothesize that home environmental context (e.g. number of people, books, and materials in the home in Spanish) and values/practices (e.g. frequency of activities to support language, parent language proficiency, parent value of home language), will impact latent dual language group membership.
RQ 3. For each latent dual language group, how do factors within the classroom impact behavior outcomes?
H 3.  Based on documented behavioral impacts for children who are unable to communicate well with teachers and peers (Olsen, 1997) and the positive relation between classroom quality and child behavior (Halle et al. 2010)  it is expected that there will be differences between latent language groups in terms of the impact of classroom and teacher characteristics on child behavior.

registration_responses.q8.question:
To identify the latent dual language groups, a parallel process latent growth model (LGM) will be conducted to simultaneously estimate the growth curves for English and Spanish.  LGM is the covariance structural equation model (SEM) representation of the multilevel model (MLM) for change. LGM is capable of adjusted standard errors for data that is nested. This is important given the structure of the current study (i.e., time nested within individuals). LGM fits a growth model with fixed (i.e., average level) and random (i.e., variability around the average) effects and correctly estimates adjusted standard errors.  In short, this is a flexible and powerful methodological approach capable of estimating growth curve models to test hypotheses about within-person change over time (i.e., intraindividual change) and between-person differences in change over time (i.e., interindividual change; Bollen, 2014; Ram & Grimm, 2007; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002; Singer & Willett, 2003).  In addition, results using these methods are robust to missing data. Due to attrition over time in the FACES dataset, not all cases are complete. The most typical method for handling incomplete (or missing) data is by using maximum likelihood estimation. This estimation method assumes repeated measures are continuous and normally distributed. Preliminary analyses will be inspected to ensure the selected data meet these assumptions.
LGM in Mplus was chosen because of some distinct advantages that fit the
 current proposal’s analytical needs: (a) the ability to handle item missing data on both the outcomes and the predictors via utilization of full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation; (b) the ability to assess model fit via global fit statistics (e.g., Confirmatory Fit Index [CFI]) to analytically evaluate and determine the best-fitting growth model; (c) the ability to model and analyze changes in multiple variables, and relationships among multiple variables, simultaneously (Chou et al., 1998; Diallo, Morin,& Parker, 2014; Ferrer et al., 2004; Willett, 2004 ).

registration_responses.q12.question:
FACES is a series of longitudinal studies of Head Start classrooms, children, and families. Researchers follow 3- and 4-year-old children from their first year in a Head Start classroom until their first year in kindergarten. Data is collected at the program, center, classroom, child, and family level. A major limitation of the previous study the current proposal is building upon was that the smallest group of children had such a limited sample size that it may have not had the power necessary to address subsequent questions. FACES, with its successive nationally representative samples, provides descriptive data from different years’ studies (FACES 2014, 2009, 2006, 2003, and so on) that may be used to analyze trends and changes in the Head Start program, the population enrolled, and the services provided. For example, it is possible to combine data from FACES 2006 and FACES 2009, as is planned for the current study. Participation rates in FACES are historically high and a total of 905 cases from Spanish-speaking households are expected to be available for analyses (456 cases from 2006; 449 cases from 2009). To facilitate cross-study comparisons, the content and naming of the measures used in the FACES instruments is structured with considerable overlap. This means that once the variables and sample of interest have been selected from each study, the files can be merged to increase the overall sample size available for planned analyses.
FACES data collection in 2006 and 2009 occurred in three waves that followed children from their first year in Head Start until the spring of their kindergarten year. Only children who are coded as Spanish-speakers, have not been identified as having a speech or language disorder at any assessment wave, and were three years old at the first wave of data collection, thus having an opportunity to experience two full years of Head Start before kindergarten, will be included in analyses. FACES data are used to answer questions about children who are dual language learners (DLL) and attend Head Start, particularly with respect to a congressionally mandated report on such children. Thus, each study provides detailed information relevant to DLL students. Additionally, for many children from non-English homes, Head Start may be the first fully immersive English experience where they are expected to participate and learn making it a critical scene to investigate dual language development and the surrounding care context.
registration_responses.q16.question: To identify the latent dual language groups, a parallel process latent growth model (LGM) will be conducted to simultaneously estimate the growth curves for English and Spanish.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Receptive vocabulary in English and Spanish was measures using the Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test (PPVT) and Test de Vocabulario en Imágenes Peabody (TVIP; Dunn, Padilla, Lugo, & Dunn, 1986) respectively. The PPVT was administered to all children in the study, regardless of home language, and the TVIP was administered to all children whose parents indicated their primary home language was Spanish.  Both measures are designed to measure receptive vocabulary of participants from age 2 and a half years to adults (Dunn & Dunn, 2006). Administration and scoring is similar across measures. Participants are shown picture plates with four pictures and asked to point to the picture that best represents a stimulus word presented orally by the examiner. The items are presented in order of increasing difficulty. Testing is discontinued after participants have made eight or more errors in a set of 12 stimulus words. One point is awarded for each correct response, and the sum of the correct responses is used as the index of receptive vocabulary. Scores may be converted into standard scores, with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15 (Dunn & Dunn, 2007). The administration manual notes the following about the PPVT’s application to English language learners: 
“The PPVT-4 instrument was normed exclusively on individuals who are proficient in English, and therefore it would not be best practice to report a normative score on this test for an individual who is not English proficient. As a criterion measure, however, the PPVT-4 scale is useful for assessing the extent and nature of a person’s knowledge of standard American English words. The early item sets of each PPVT-4 form include high-frequency, commonly used words. These words can aid in screening individuals for whom English is not the primary language and in planning interventions for those who want to attain English proficiency.” (Dunn & Dunn, 2007, p.3)
Split-half reliability and alpha coefficients are consistently high at all ages and grades (Dunn & Dunn, 2007). The FACES User Guide indicates that the Cronbach alpha scores across time points ranged from 0.91 to 0.97 for the PPVT and 0.89 to 0.94 for the TVIP (Malone et al., 2013). Average test-retest reliability is reported to be .93 (Malone et al., 2013). The PPVT demonstrates convergent validity as it has been found to correlate with two established tests of expressive vocabulary: the Expressive Vocabulary Test, Second Edition (.80 to .84), and the Comprehensive Assessment of Spoken Language (mid-.60s to high .70s; Dunn & Dunn, 2007). All children participating in FACES testing were administered the PPVT. Split half reliabilities of the TVIP range from .80 to .94 (Dunn et al., 1986). The content validity of the measure with the Kauffman Assessment Battery for Children Spanish ranged from .25 to .56 and concurrent validity was .44 with the Habilidad General Ability Test (Dunn et al., 1986).
Child gender will be included as a control variable in analyses targeted at identifying latent language groups because gender has been shown to influence language development in both monolinguals and bilinguals. Studies of monolingual language development report female children tend to have a larger vocabulary than males of the same age (Huttenlocher, Haight, Bryk, Seltzer, & Lyons, 1991). Studies of DLL students have mixed results related to whether gender makes a significant impact on English language learning (Greenberg-Motamedi, 2015; Grissom, 2004; Thompson, 2017; Uriarte et al., 2011), or experience no differences related to dual language development vocabulary (Hammer, Davison, Lawrence, & Miccio, 2009).
Child Problem and Prosocial Behavior were both collected from both parents and teachers. Taken together, the parent and teacher ratings permitted a comparison of assessment items for a given child and allowed construction of composites of children’s social behavior across settings and data sources. However, given that different behaviors may be more or less salient in the home versus the classroom, a subset of items in the rating scales is unique to each setting and data source.
Parents and teachers were asked to rate each child on a set of behaviors that assessed the child’s basic social skill and behavior problems. The ratings included items drawn from the Personal Maturity Scale, Social Skills Rating System (SSRS; Gresham and Elliott 1990; Elliott et al. 1988) and Behavior Problems Index (BPI; Peterson and Zill 1986). Teachers and parents indicated the extent to which a given statement (such as “makes friends easily”) was characteristic of the child, from 1 (“never”) to 3 (“very often”). Summary scores were created from the three-point scale items.
Items in the FACES behavior problems scale, which measure negative child behaviors associated with learning problems, come from an abbreviated adaptation of the Personal Maturity Scale and from the Behavior Problems Index (BPI; Peterson and Zill 1986). The BPI included undercontrol (such as aggression, hyperactivity, and destructiveness) and overcontrol (such as social withdrawal, depression, and somatic problems) behaviors; the internal consistency of the BPI total score ranged from 0.88 to 0.89 in the National Health Interview Survey and the National Longitudinal Study of Youth (NLSY) (Berry et al. 2004). Given that the BPI does not adequately assess pro-social or positive behaviors, additional items for the parent and teacher rating scales were taken from the SSRS and from the Personal Maturity Scale..
The Personal Maturity Scale was originally used in the 1976–1977 National Survey of Children (Zill and Daly 1993) and later adapted by Alexander and Entwisle for use in their longitudinal study of achievement of Baltimore’s inner-city elementary school children (Alexander and Entwisle 1988). The scale, which measured a child’s interest or participation, cooperation or compliance, and attention span or restlessness, consists of 13 items forming three subscales, with alpha reliabilities ranging from 0.74 to 0.85. The SSRS social skills scale’s alpha coefficients range from 0.87 to 0.90 for parent reports across the elementary and preschool SSRS forms, respectively, and 0.94 for the teacher forms.
Parent interviews were collected from participating families via computer-assisted personal and telephone interviews conducted in Spanish and English. A rich resources of information is available including demographic information (e.g. immigration status, maternal education), information specific to the presence and value of Spanish in the home (e.g. number of people, books, and materials in the home in Spanish, how proficient the respondent is in English in Spanish, how valuable home and English language is to the respondent), and questions addressing the home learning environment. 
In FACES, information about activities with children come from previous national surveys, including the NHES and Home Observation for Measurement of the Environment (HOME) Inventory, a standard measure of the quality of the language and learning environment in the home. FACES obtained information about the frequency of various types of stimulating or educational activities with the child, such as singing songs or nursery rhymes, counting together, visiting the park, and shopping or running errands. These items, drawn from national surveys, were used to form scales that assessed the parent’s participation in the child’s educational experiences and cognitive stimulation. 
Classroom variables available for analyses include observational measures of quality, teacher characteristics, and curriculum and support specific to DLL students. Observational measures of the classroom include the Instructional Support (instructional support, concept development, and language modeling) domain of the Classroom Assessment Scoring System (CLASS; Pianta et al., 2008) and the Early Childhood Environment Rating Scale–Revised (ECERS–R).   
The CLASS observes and assesses the quality of interactions between teachers and students in classrooms and measures aspects of interactions related to children’s early academic achievement and social competencies. Each dimension is rated on a seven-point scale (1 = “minimally characteristic” to 7 = “highly characteristic”) for each of four observation cycles. For Instructional Support domain, publisher-reported internal consistency = 0.79, correlation between two observations as an indicator of test-retest reliability = 0.86, and average inter-rater reliability (within one point of rating from master raters) is 87 percent (Pianata et al., 2008). 
The Early Childhood Environment Rating Scale–Revised (ECERS–R) is a global rating of classroom quality based on structural features of the classroom (Harms et al. 2005). The classroom environment is defined as the use of space, materials, and experiences to enhance children’s development, daily schedule, and supervision. Even though child development research has made wide use of the ECERS–R to predict optimal child outcomes (for example, Phillips et al. 1994), research studies have not consistently supported the seven-scale factor structure of the full ECERS–R (Malone et al. 2010). Accordingly, FACES used a subset of items from the ECERS–R which has also been used by the Multi-State Study of Prekindergarten, the State-Wide Early Education Program (SWEEP; Early et al. 2005), and the Chicago Program Evaluation Project (C-PEP) study (Ross et al. 2008). The items in the short form represent the strongest 21 items identified by researchers in a large-scale study (Clifford et al. 2005) and form two factors: Teaching and Interactions (that is, the quality of teacher-child interactions) and Provisions for Learning (that is, materials available in the classroom and the arrangement of the classroom space). Each of the two factors encompasses 11 to 12 items, with each item rated on a seven-point scale that denotes a level of quality associated with the scale score. A score of one is considered “inadequate,” 3 is “minimal quality,” 5 is “good quality,” and 7 is “excellent quality.” In spring 2010 and spring 2011 of FACES 2009, the internal consistency reliability (Cronbach’s alpha) for the Teaching and Interactions mean score and the Provisions for Learning mean score ranged, respectively, from 0.84 to 0.85 and from 0.80 to 0.84. For the ECERS–R, inter-rater reliability for the full scale ranges from 0.85 (rank-order correlations) to 0.92 (Pearson), and inter-rater reliability on individual items reached agreement of 71 percent for agreement within one point. Internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha) ranged from 0.71 (parents and staff) to 0.88 (activities), with an alpha coefficient of 0.92 for the full scale (Harms et al. 2005).
Teacher characteristics, are a set of structural factors related to child care quality, include teacher education and training. The Head Start teacher interview asked about the classroom teacher’s teaching experience (number of years teaching in Head Start), educational background (the highest grade or year of school completed), teaching credentials (for example, Child Development Associate), salary, and demographics (age, gender, race/ethnicity). Additionally, teacher’s Teachers’ knowledge and beliefs about best teaching practices for early childhood education was collected using 15 statements representing opinions on how Head Start children should be taught and managed (Burts et al. 1990). Two statements posit that “Head Start classroom activities should be responsive to individual differences in development” and “Students should work silently and alone on seatwork.” The Head Start teacher indicated whether and to what extent he or she agreed or disagreed with each statement based on a five-point Likert type scale (1 = “strongly disagree”; 5 = “strongly agree”).
Presence of overt DLL support provided is also collected through questions asked in teacher and program interviews. Surveys ask about what specific curriculum are used and if there is guidance provided to support language development of DLL children. Respondents were asked questions about the language demographic in the classroom such as how many adults and children in the classroom speak Spanish, who in the classroom uses Spanish for instruction and speaking to the group, and the availability of materials in Spanish in the classroom. Finally, interviews also asked teachers to rate their proficiency speaking and understanding Spanish.
registration_responses.q19.question:
To identify the latent dual language groups, a parallel process latent growth model (LGM) will be conducted to simultaneously estimate the growth curves for English and Spanish.  LGM is the covariance structural equation model (SEM) representation of the multilevel model (MLM) for change. LGM is capable of adjusted standard errors for data that is nested. This is important given the structure of the current study (i.e., time nested within individuals). LGM fits a growth model with fixed (i.e., average level) and random (i.e., variability around the average) effects and correctly estimates adjusted standard errors.  In short, this is a flexible and powerful methodological approach capable of estimating growth curve models to test hypotheses about within-person change over time (i.e., intraindividual change) and between-person differences in change over time (i.e., interindividual change; Bollen, 2014; Ram & Grimm, 2007; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002; Singer & Willett, 2003).  In addition, results using these methods are robust to missing data. Due to attrition over time in the FACES dataset, not all cases are complete. The most typical method for handling incomplete (or missing) data is by using maximum likelihood estimation. This estimation method assumes repeated measures are continuous and normally distributed. Preliminary analyses will be inspected to ensure the selected data meet these assumptions.
LGM in Mplus was chosen because of some distinct advantages that fit the
 current proposal’s analytical needs: (a) the ability to handle item missing data on both the outcomes and the predictors via utilization of full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation; (b) the ability to assess model fit via global fit statistics (e.g., Confirmatory Fit Index [CFI]) to analytically evaluate and determine the best-fitting growth model; (c) the ability to model and analyze changes in multiple variables, and relationships among multiple variables, simultaneously (Chou et al., 1998; Diallo, Morin,& Parker, 2014; Ferrer et al., 2004; Willett, 2004 ).
A limitation of the previous study was inability to test non-linear trajectories. Due to the number of missing cases at the fourth time point (kindergarten) the previous project selected to only included three timepoints whereas four time points are required to test quadradic slopes. However, with twice the sample size afforded by linking the 2006 and 2009 studies, it is expected that sufficient cases from Spanish-speaking households will be available at the final data collections point to test latent quadratic slopes (non-linear trajectories). This is an important extension of the previous research with receptive language particularly because a similar study using expressive language detected non-linear dual language patterns (Escobar & Tamis-LeMonda, 2017).
As a first step to conduct a parallel process analysis, separate models will be fitted to English and Spanish vocabulary raw scores, thus, all of the following steps will be completed for English and Spanish separately. First, intercept-only first-order latent growth curve models (LGCM) will be examined. In the baseline models, all cases will be considered to have identical growth patterns, means, variances, and covariances. All parameters are constrained to be equivalent across groups. In essence, the model is forced to assume all students belong to a single-group.
Next, fit statistics for linear and non-linear LGC models will be compared to intercept-only models. Then, random effects of the linear models were inspected. In contrast to fixed-effects (i.e., the sample's mean value for intercept and slope) random effects indicate the amount of variability around the sample's mean value for intercept and slope. In order to proceed with investigating if time-invariant predictors explain variability in random effects, these values must be statistically significant. The addition of covariates is intended to explain the observed variability around the sample’s mean intercept and slope. If random effects are statistically significant, child gender (the only time-invariant covariate planned for inclusion) will be entered on the slopes and intercepts of the two separate models. Covariates will be set to their individual variances as a requirement of time-invariant variables in LGCM. If child gender is not statistically significant it will be dropped from the final parallel process model.
The two resulting models (one for Spanish, one for English) will be combined into a single parallel-process model. Residual variances for each outcome variable will be constrained to be equal over the three measurement occasions. Syntax will be added to prompt the generation of data-driven groups based on students’ Spanish and English language scores. To account for the possibility that there may be more or fewer unobserved groups than hypothesized, models were tested with 2, 3, 4, and 5 group solutions. Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) was compared between models to determine the best-fitting model (Nylund, Asparouhov, & Muthén, 2007). The number and nature of groups in the final best fitting model will be described.
A total of 905 cases are expected to be available for analyses. Using an equation for estimating power in latent class analyses (Dziak, Lanza, & Tan, 2014) a model with 3 classes, and 4 variables (Spanish vocabulary, English vocabulary, and child gender), an effect size of .17 is needed to have 80% power to reject the null hypothesis with the current estimated sample size. This ranges between the benchmarks for a small (.10) and medium (.30) effect size (Cohen, 1988).
Research question one:   Does latent dual language group membership differentially predict behavior outcomes? A multivariate regression analysis will test the relation between latent language group and behavior outcomes. In this analysis, dual language membership will essentially be treated as a categorical variable as assigned through the process described above. As a precaution, an intraclass correlation coefficient analyses will first be conducted to inspect the proportion of between-unit variance to total variance. As described previously, FACES used a multi-stage clustered sampling technique. Unlike simple random sampling, it is expected that observations are not independent because there are inherent clusters at each stage of sampling. Children in the same program, center, or classroom, are more likely to share similar characteristics due to being drawn from the same environment. An intraclass correlation will be conducted at the program, center, and teacher level to describe how similar student’s scores are at each level. The intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs), indicate the proportion of between-unit variance to total variance. In addition to providing contextual information about language scores, the presence of significant clustering can lead to considerable bias in the results of tests of statistical significance in conventional OLS regression analyses, which does not take the dependence of observations into account (Cohen, Cohen, West & Aiken, 2003). In previous work using data from Spanish-speaking children in the FACES dataset has not indicated a significant amount of clustering that requires a more complex analytic method to account for clustering and it is expected a regression analysis will be sufficiently sophisticated to answer research questions one. 
Descriptive analyses and preliminary correlations of all variables of interest will first be inspected to ensure the distribution of scores relation between covariates and outcomes meet assumptions. Latent dual language group will be dummy coded based on model generated assignment. Regression analysis has been selected because it allows for the inclusion of multiple covariates to be entered into the model. This will be important as we expect to include family demographic variables, child gender, and initial behavioral scores as control variables in order to tease out the distinct impact of language group on behavior. With a total sample size of 905 cases a power analysis, using G*Power, indicates that an analysis with an error probability of p < .05, testing 5 predictors (e.g. child gender, initial behavior, maternal education, length of time in the U.S, and family income) has sufficient power (.92) to detect a small effect (.02).
The results will provide links from a holistic view of dual language development to behavior development. Results will inform discussions with the partner Head Start site to develop person-centered strategies focused on the unique strengths and needs of DLL students in the Head Start program. 
Research question two: After controlling for demographic factors, are there significant differences between latent dual language groups in terms of family and home environment factors? An analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) will be used to address this research question. This technique allows for the inspection of between group differences on key family and home environment outcomes while accounting/controlling for differences that might be attributable to group membership. ANCOVA is used to remove noise from the analysis that was induced by random differences between groups. Because it is impossible to randomly assign children to be a part of a specific dual language group, group assignment is not randomized meaning there may be confounding effects on the outcome variable of interest. Thus, this analytic method would permit controlling for demographic variables, such as maternal education, to inspect the specific differences between group averages on the family outcome variable of interest.
Understanding how family and home environment factors differ between groups can provide clues for programs to understand what developmental pattern a child might be headed towards beyond their presenting language ability. Findings may additionally provide insight into key variables that meaningfully impact child language development which may prove to be useful points of leverage for families as they make choices that guide children toward the language development trajectory of most value to them.
Research question three: For each latent dual language group, how do factors within the classroom impact behavior outcomes? An intercepts-and-slopes-as-outcomes multilevel regression analysis (Luke, 2004) will be used to answer this question. This type of analysis allows researchers to inspect both random intercepts and random slopes with predictors at both the individual level and the cluster level. 
Most importantly, this approach allows for the ability to test potential interaction effects between the individual level predictors and cluster level predictors. This means that we can inspect whether there is a difference between dual language groups in respect to how classroom level variables, such as teacher education, impact child behavior. Teacher education is a cluster level variable because it varies between, but not within, each Head Start classroom. In other words, all the children in the same classroom are experiencing the same teacher characteristics. The impact these cluster level variables have on behavior outcomes will provide direction for person-specific strategies for teachers. Results would provide direction to tailor classroom support to meeting the unique needs of DLL children based on differences observed based on latent dual language group.

q1.value: “If you won’t let me play, I will hurt you”: The effect of ostracism on indicators of radicalisation using the Cyberball paradigm

q3.value:
The experience of social exclusion or ostracism are common explanations for starting the process of radicalisation. The present research examines this relationship and proposes a mediation effect of threat to four fundamental human needs: for belonging, self-esteem, control and meaningful existence. Ostracism is manipulated in a 2 x 2 experimental online design: Participants are either themselves ostracised or included or watch another in-group member being ostracised or included. Radicalisation is measured as advocating extremist views and supporting violent and criminal acts to achieve goals related to these views. We add two dimensions measuring whether participants would use legal means or do nothing regarding these goals, to capture a broader variety of reactions to experiencing ostracism. We hypothesise that participants in both exclusion conditions will show higher need threat, which in turns predicts proneness to radicalisation. Data will be analysed using structural equation modelling.
There will be a small pilot study for the purpose of obtaining reliability estimations for two new additional dimensions in the "Pro-violence and Illegal Acts in Relation to Extremism Scale (PIARES)” by Ozer & Bertelsen (2018).

q4.value: We predict that people in the inclusion conditions will show higher need satisfaction, which is negatively associated with the positive indicators of radicalisation, namely extremism, pro-violence and illegal acts. We assume higher need satisfaction to be positively associated with acting within the legal framework or not acting at all. To the contrary, participants in the ostracism condition are assumed to show lower need satisfaction, which is associated with higher manifestations of extremism, pro-violence and illegal acts, depicted by a negative correlation. We assume lower need satisfaction to be associated with lower values in acting within the legal framework or not acting at all.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The aim of the present research is to investigate the effect of ostracism, experienced by oneself as well as observing an in-group member being ostracised, on indicators of radicalisation, mediated by the needs for belonging, control, self-esteem and meaningful existence. We will employ a 2 (ostracism: exclusion vs. inclusion) x 2 (self vs. other) between-subjects experimental design embedded in an online survey, using Cyberball for manipulating ostracism. For the purpose of operationalising in-group membership, participants choose a representation of their ethnic identity to depict them in the Cyberball game.

q9.value: We will use block randomisation with the goal of achieving equal sample size in all four conditions using Qualtrics (60 participants / block).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants will be paid 2 US-Dollars for participating. 
In the pilot study, we recruit first-year Psychology students at the University of Amsterdam for the pilot study, aiming to estimate reliability of the two additional dimensions of the radicalisations measure. They will participate in exchange for course credit. 
Participants will only be excluded if they fail attention checks or manipulation checks.

q13.value: We aim for 240 participants in the main analysis and approximately 50 participants in the pilot study.

q14.value: Power analysis for SEM was conducted based on the tool by Preacher and Coffman (2006), which uses RMSEA for computing the minimum sample size required for a given level of power. Indicating an alpha of 0.05, 45 degrees of freedom, a desired power of 0.80 and indicating 0.05 as null and 0.08 as alternative values of RMSEA, the resulting minimum necessary sample size to achieve the desired power is 230.

question.value:
Ostracism (Manipulated through Cyberball game)
Participants are randomly assigned to one of the four conditions and complete the Cyberball game. Before that, they choose an avatar with whom they identify to represent them in the game. These avatars will consist of emojis depicting different ethnic or national identities; this is used to make their social identity salient. Adopting the classical narrative used in the Cyberball paradigm (see Zadro et al., 2004), participants will be told that they are supposed to practice their mental visualisation skills by playing a ball-toss game on the computer with other participants, connected through the internet. They will be told that performance is unimportant, but that they should focus on visualising themselves, the situation and the other players. Participants in the “other”-condition are told to watch a specific player (“player 2”) and visualise the same aspects but from his or her perspective. Player 2 will be represented by the same emoji participants chose before but of the opposite gender, to indicate it is indeed a different person. The simulated players will also introduce themselves briefly in a chat window. Participants are instructed to throw the ball to one of the other players if the receive it or to watch the throws in the “other”-condition. The game is set to a total of 30 throws in all conditions, where inclusion is defined as receiving the ball 1/3 of the time and exclusion as receiving it only twice within the first 5 throws but not after that. After the game, participants are redirected to the questionnaire. Survey length will be approximately 15 minutes, based on an average of 8 seconds per items and a duration of 5 minutes playing Cyberball.

The survey contains scales measuring 9 factors in total, as well as a check on the success of the manipulation. Demographic questions asking about age, gender, education, employment status and ethnicity are also included. The whole questionnaire intended to be used in the main analysis can be found in the appendix.

Need satisfaction. Need satisfaction will be measured using a scale taken from Jamieson et al. (2010). It consists of four scales with 5 items each, measuring satisfaction of need for control (e.g. “I felt I had control over the course of the game”), need for meaningful existence (e.g. “I felt important”), need for self-esteem (e.g. “I felt liked”) and need for belonging (“I felt I belonged to the group”). Answers are given on a 5-point scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely). These items are specifically designed to be used after the Cyberball manipulation, however Jamieson et al. (2010) do not indicate estimations of reliability or validity, only correlations between scales. They are correlated significantly, between .43 and .68 in study 1 and between .32 and .69 in study 2.

Radicalisation. Indicators of radicalisation consist of the “Extremism Scale” as well as the “Pro-violence and Illegal Acts in Relation to Extremism Scale (PIARES)” by Ozer & Bertelsen (2018). The former examines participants extremist mindset, including items like “Most people in this country have a lifestyle and culture that is necessary to change totally.” or “It is a waste of time to try to find common solutions with those whose thoughts about life are completely different than ours.”. The latter asks whether participants support the use of violence or breaking the law in order to achieve certain goals related to the extremist mindset. Thus, this scale is not explicitly related to the ostracism manipulation but refers to a general state of mind after the ostracism experience. The Extremism Scale consists of 14 items and the PIARES consists of 12 items, 6 for each dimension. Items are scored on a seven-point Likert scale ranging from (1) “Strongly disagree” to (7) “Strongly agree”. The measurement was validated on 686 Danish and US-American high school and college students using exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis, yielding satisfactory results, as well as construct validity through correlations with criteria scales. There are no estimates of reliability given.
Similar to PIARES, we will add two dimensions with the same items, however asking whether participants would try to achieve these goals using legal means (termed “Legal Means in Relation to Extremism”) and whether they would not take action at all when it comes to these goals (termed “No Acts in Relation to Extremism”). Thereby, we hope to capture a broader variety of the effect of ostracism and need threat. This extended questionnaire will be tested before the main study on a sample of about 50 participants to establish reliability. However, if the pilot study indicates insufficient reliability of these two extra dimensions, they will be excluded from the main analysis.

Manipulation Check. For evaluating the success of the ostracism manipulation, several items will be used to assess perception of inclusion. These items are taken from (Zadro et al., 2004; see also Jamieson et al., 2010) and are the following: “What percent of the throws were thrown to you?” or “What percent of the throws were thrown to player 2”, “To what extent were you included by the other participants during the game?” or “To what extend was player 2 included by the other participants during the game?” (rated on a 7-point Likert scale) and a 9-point bipolar scale asking how participants or player 2 felt during the game, consisting of the poles “rejected” and “accepted”.

Attention Check. Throughout the survey, a total of 6 items measuring attentiveness of the respondent are included, asking to indicate a specific answer (e.g. “This is an attention check, please choose the answer "Not at all".”).
We will work with SEM using mean scores of obtained measures.

We will run a structural regression model, using the four conditions as predictors; needs for belonging, self-esteem, control and meaningful existence as mediators; and 5 outcome variables: extremism, pro-violence in relation to extremism, illegal acts in relation to extremism, legal means in relation to extremism, and no acts in relation to extremism. A simplified representation of the model is attached; please note that due to clarity, error indicators and some arrows/relationships are missing. However, the two inclusion conditions are assumed to lead to higher need satisfaction, whereas the two exclusion conditions are assumed to lead to lower need satisfaction. This is assumed for all four needs. 
Higher need satisfaction in each need in turn is associated with a lower manifestation of extremism, pro-violence and illegal acts, represented by a negative correlation as well as higher values in legal means and no acts, represented by a positive correlation. 
Lower need satisfaction in each need in turn is associated with a higher manifestation of extremism, pro-violence and illegal acts, represented by a negative correlation as well as lower values in legal means and no acts, represented by a positive correlation.

q21.value: For evaluating model fit, we will rely on model fit indices including CFI, TLI, RMSEA, GFI or MFI, however p-value of chi-square test will also be reported since it is common in the literature.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if they fail the attention checks or if their answers on the manipulation checks indicate they felt excluded in the inclusion condition or included in the exclusion condition  or if their estimate of the times the received the ball is wrong, e.g. 50% below or above the actual throws.

q23.value:
If data is missing, the data set will be reviewed to check that it is non-random; it will then be replaced using multiple imputation. 
However, since we distribute the survey via Amazon Mechanical Turk in exchange for payment and include attention checks, we estimate that there will not be a lot of missing data.

registration_responses.q8.question: The aim of the present research is to investigate the effect of ostracism, experienced by oneself as well as observing an in-group member being ostracised, on indicators of radicalisation, mediated by the needs for belonging, control, self-esteem and meaningful existence. We will employ a 2 (ostracism: exclusion vs. inclusion) x 2 (self vs. other) between-subjects experimental design embedded in an online survey, using Cyberball for manipulating ostracism. For the purpose of operationalising in-group membership, participants choose a representation of their ethnic identity to depict them in the Cyberball game.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants will be paid 2 US-Dollars for participating. 
In the pilot study, we recruit first-year Psychology students at the University of Amsterdam for the pilot study, aiming to estimate reliability of the two additional dimensions of the radicalisations measure. They will participate in exchange for course credit. 
Participants will only be excluded if they fail attention checks or manipulation checks.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Ostracism (Manipulated through Cyberball game)
Participants are randomly assigned to one of the four conditions and complete the Cyberball game. Before that, they choose an avatar with whom they identify to represent them in the game. These avatars will consist of emojis depicting different ethnic or national identities; this is used to make their social identity salient. Adopting the classical narrative used in the Cyberball paradigm (see Zadro et al., 2004), participants will be told that they are supposed to practice their mental visualisation skills by playing a ball-toss game on the computer with other participants, connected through the internet. They will be told that performance is unimportant, but that they should focus on visualising themselves, the situation and the other players. Participants in the “other”-condition are told to watch a specific player (“player 2”) and visualise the same aspects but from his or her perspective. Player 2 will be represented by the same emoji participants chose before but of the opposite gender, to indicate it is indeed a different person. The simulated players will also introduce themselves briefly in a chat window. Participants are instructed to throw the ball to one of the other players if the receive it or to watch the throws in the “other”-condition. The game is set to a total of 30 throws in all conditions, where inclusion is defined as receiving the ball 1/3 of the time and exclusion as receiving it only twice within the first 5 throws but not after that. After the game, participants are redirected to the questionnaire. Survey length will be approximately 15 minutes, based on an average of 8 seconds per items and a duration of 5 minutes playing Cyberball.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The survey contains scales measuring 9 factors in total, as well as a check on the success of the manipulation. Demographic questions asking about age, gender, education, employment status and ethnicity are also included. The whole questionnaire intended to be used in the main analysis can be found in the appendix.

Need satisfaction. Need satisfaction will be measured using a scale taken from Jamieson et al. (2010). It consists of four scales with 5 items each, measuring satisfaction of need for control (e.g. “I felt I had control over the course of the game”), need for meaningful existence (e.g. “I felt important”), need for self-esteem (e.g. “I felt liked”) and need for belonging (“I felt I belonged to the group”). Answers are given on a 5-point scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely). These items are specifically designed to be used after the Cyberball manipulation, however Jamieson et al. (2010) do not indicate estimations of reliability or validity, only correlations between scales. They are correlated significantly, between .43 and .68 in study 1 and between .32 and .69 in study 2.

Radicalisation. Indicators of radicalisation consist of the “Extremism Scale” as well as the “Pro-violence and Illegal Acts in Relation to Extremism Scale (PIARES)” by Ozer & Bertelsen (2018). The former examines participants extremist mindset, including items like “Most people in this country have a lifestyle and culture that is necessary to change totally.” or “It is a waste of time to try to find common solutions with those whose thoughts about life are completely different than ours.”. The latter asks whether participants support the use of violence or breaking the law in order to achieve certain goals related to the extremist mindset. Thus, this scale is not explicitly related to the ostracism manipulation but refers to a general state of mind after the ostracism experience. The Extremism Scale consists of 14 items and the PIARES consists of 12 items, 6 for each dimension. Items are scored on a seven-point Likert scale ranging from (1) “Strongly disagree” to (7) “Strongly agree”. The measurement was validated on 686 Danish and US-American high school and college students using exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis, yielding satisfactory results, as well as construct validity through correlations with criteria scales. There are no estimates of reliability given.
Similar to PIARES, we will add two dimensions with the same items, however asking whether participants would try to achieve these goals using legal means (termed “Legal Means in Relation to Extremism”) and whether they would not take action at all when it comes to these goals (termed “No Acts in Relation to Extremism”). Thereby, we hope to capture a broader variety of the effect of ostracism and need threat. This extended questionnaire will be tested before the main study on a sample of about 50 participants to establish reliability. However, if the pilot study indicates insufficient reliability of these two extra dimensions, they will be excluded from the main analysis.

Manipulation Check. For evaluating the success of the ostracism manipulation, several items will be used to assess perception of inclusion. These items are taken from (Zadro et al., 2004; see also Jamieson et al., 2010) and are the following: “What percent of the throws were thrown to you?” or “What percent of the throws were thrown to player 2”, “To what extent were you included by the other participants during the game?” or “To what extend was player 2 included by the other participants during the game?” (rated on a 7-point Likert scale) and a 9-point bipolar scale asking how participants or player 2 felt during the game, consisting of the poles “rejected” and “accepted”.

Attention Check. Throughout the survey, a total of 6 items measuring attentiveness of the respondent are included, asking to indicate a specific answer (e.g. “This is an attention check, please choose the answer "Not at all".”).
registration_responses.q18.question: We will work with SEM using mean scores of obtained measures.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will run a structural regression model, using the four conditions as predictors; needs for belonging, self-esteem, control and meaningful existence as mediators; and 5 outcome variables: extremism, pro-violence in relation to extremism, illegal acts in relation to extremism, legal means in relation to extremism, and no acts in relation to extremism. A simplified representation of the model is attached; please note that due to clarity, error indicators and some arrows/relationships are missing. However, the two inclusion conditions are assumed to lead to higher need satisfaction, whereas the two exclusion conditions are assumed to lead to lower need satisfaction. This is assumed for all four needs. 
Higher need satisfaction in each need in turn is associated with a lower manifestation of extremism, pro-violence and illegal acts, represented by a negative correlation as well as higher values in legal means and no acts, represented by a positive correlation. 
Lower need satisfaction in each need in turn is associated with a higher manifestation of extremism, pro-violence and illegal acts, represented by a negative correlation as well as lower values in legal means and no acts, represented by a positive correlation.
